With the Echo Flex plugged in, and connected, all of the voice recognition was going through the Flex and the Smart Clock no longer did the countdown with a timer, as it did with the Echo. I unplugged the Echo Flex. The smart clock worked fine. I think if you have a bigger house and more rooms to cover, using the Echo Flex is a good way to get more coverage. But in our small apartment, it isn't necessary. I can control the Echo in our living room, from our bedroom. When the Echo Flex was plugged in, it seemed to recognize my voice well. But the speaker on it reminds me of playing something through a small speaker on a cheap cassette player. Remember those? It is hollow and tinny and would not be a good vehicle for music or other audio. If Amazon could come up with a smart plug directly tied into the Alexa range, I would buy that.
title: Possibly Good For Some Situations... But There Are Problems

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Lenny
content: I have this in my garage, where it's more useful than I expected. I originally got this so that I can turn on the garage light when I come in from the side door (the light switch is at the other side of the garage, near the kitchen entrance). I set up an Alexa routine so that it will turn on the light for a minute, giving me enough time to walk to the other end of the garage to enter the house without tripping over things, before turning itself off. So far that has worked very well. The USB port also turned out to be more useful than I expected. With so many things that recharge from USB these days, such as my bicycle headlights, it's nice to have another charger in the garage. I measured the charging current at 1.6A, I'm not sure if that's the maximum current, or just how much my light draws when recharging, but it is more than I expected. Finally, having it as a plug in form factor saves me the hassle and expense of getting a separate mount for it. Downsides, the speaker is not as good. It specifically says it's not suitable for playing music, but within a few days of using this, Alexa said that I haven't asked it to play music and if I would like to do so. I guess someone didn't program it properly. Finally, the microphone isn't as good as the other Echo devices I have. Even the 1st generation Echo Dot does a better job of recognizing my commands when there's extra noise in the background. Overall, for the price and utility, it deserves 5 stars.
title: Inexpensive device for where you don't need to play music

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Discriminating Buyer
content: I've been putting in echo dots and shows around the house, really to be used as an intercom/announcement system and for control of some smart items.  My parents are elderly and my Mom had a stroke a few years ago so I prefer to have some sort of communication system around that is voice activated (as long as they can speak) in an emergency.  It's also proved handy for them to control lights, view some cctv cams, fans, the air conditioning, etc. I bought the flex used based on the poor reviews that it got, I figured that if they didn't work at least I wasn't out the cost of a new one.  I wanted these for areas where I don't have dots.  Setup was probably easier than any other Echo device I've had.  It apparently uses bluetooth so that has to be turned on on the phone.  I did a test speaking close into the dot and it transmitted to all the other echo devices.  The sound from it isn't that bad, I was expecting some really tinny sound but Alexa sounds much the same as on the other devices.  I haven't tried music on it to see how that sounds but I did make Alexa sing the 20 second wash your hands song and it sounded okay. UPDATE I tried music on it and while it wasn't terrific it wasn't all that bad. I decided to put this in the carport instead up near the ceiling and it definitely is tinny sounding there and not very loud.  I maxed the volume through the app and it still wasn't very loud.  It seems to hear okay though.
title: Better than I expected!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Sharon Clark
content: I bought this for the basement as I am terrified of falling down my cement steps and being unable to get help.  I placed it in the center of the basement in the only available outlet.  Volume goes up to 10, which, unfortunately, is very low for my slightly impaired hearing.  I need to be within a few feet to hear it at all and ideally within a few inches to understand.  I have an echo plus and a couple of dots and have them about halfway because they can be loud.  The flex at full is way too quiet, would never buy another and wouldn't recommend for that reason.  That being said, I really only need it if I fall down the steps and need to call for help.  I have asked the time, etc occasionally from the flex, it does hear me better than I can hear it so I have protection from "I've fallen and can't get up".  Old ladies living alone need inexpensive safety measures and this one is great for that.
title: Works great and gives piece of mind

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Clayton M.
content: I bought this for my mother, who has been looking for a nightlight for her bathroom. Paired with the ThirdReality smart night-light accessory , this lovely little Alexa device gives you peace of mind in areas you can't easily place one of the larger Echo devices with a surprisingly bright adjustable LED lamp. The pictures I've attached show the night-light using the sensor mode - it's off when the lights are on, and turns on when the room gets dark. You can see also that it shows as a controllable light in the Alexa app. There are several colors to pick from and a slider to set brightness; I have it set to 2% here because the bathroom is connected to a bedroom - the light can definitely be much brighter if you want that. === PROS === - Small form factor doesn't take up space. - Plug on the bottom lets you mix and match accessories (night-light, motion sensor, etc). - If you don't want an accessory, use the bottom plug to charge your phone! - Works great with mid-wall plugs like those you find in bathrooms (near the counter) or kitchens (by the sink). - Use a 3.5mm cable or Bluetooth to connect a dedicated speaker for playing music. === CONS === - Audio quality is ok, not meant for music playback using the built-in speaker. Very tempted to buy a couple more of these on sale; I am sure I can find a few more spots in our home that could be introduced to Alexa!
title: Makes a great smart nightlight

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Adrienne Boswell
content: We live in a two-bedroom apartment.  We have an Echo Dot in the living room that shares a table with a Google Home Mini.  Then I have an Echo Dot in my bedroom, and my son has a Google Home Mini in his bedroom.  I also have a Fire Tablet in the kitchen that I use for recipes, music, etc.  There was only one room missing in order to make this apartment fully Amazoned out - the bathroom.  Now, Alexa can hear me no matter where I am in the house, and I really like that. But, besides that, I like having an echo in the bathroom so I know what time it is, so I can listen to music or my morning routine, check the weather, all without having to go into the bedroom or living room.  I know, first world problems, but it works for me. I just answered a question about if you can use the Flex to make phone calls.  Yes, you can.  It's not a Bose speaker quality, but, I have to say, it's actually better than my phone sometimes is. So, I can chat on the phone when I'm getting ready, too.  Nice. I really like that it's so small and plugs right into the wall outlet.  It doesn't take up much space, and especially in the bathroom where counter space is at a premium, it's great that it can live on the wall and not the counter. I recommend the Flex if you want Alexa coverage all over your home.  These little ones are inexpensive, small and unobtrusive. Great product.
title: Great new member of the family

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: A fan from Meriden, CT
content: Its has been a while since I wrote an Amazon Review, but I felt I had to for this. It is a WONDERFUL Product ! I already had a 1st Gen Echo Dot that is setup in my living room. And after some early trepidations, everyone in my family uses it. I got a smart light to go along with it & that is great as well. So when I recently got a couple more smart lights to set up in my Office, I needed another echo to control that. And that's why I got the Flex. My office is in the basement so using the Echo in the living room to control the lights isn't ideal. All I needed was something small, so the flex is a perfect fit. I just tucked it into a corner by my stereo receiver and plugged it into a short extension cord. Bingo ! Now I have full Alexa capability downstairs. I use it to turn on the lights (I added a smart plug to my desk lamp as well) when I come downstairs to start my day & it can hear me easily from across the room. And while the sound of the on-board speaker isn't great, I plugged it into the Audio Input on my stereo & now it sounds FABULOUS. What else do I need, ? And at only HALF the price of a Dot (and a quarter of the price of a full size Echo) why WOULDN'T you get one ? Thanks for making this, Amazon - it's perfect ! UPDATE: Make that slightly LESS than perfect. Please be aware this may not be the Echo's fault ... BUT I have had to redo the WiFi connection on it TWICE since setting it up. I thought rthat maybe it was an issue witth My Amazon Connectivity in General, but I verified that the Dot in the Living room & my App both work fine - its just the Flex. And its not because the Flex is farther away, its MUCH Closer, The Router is literally NEXT TO where the Flex is installed. And there are no sources of interference nearby that I am aware of. The only thing I can think of is my son does have a WiFi extender set up in the living room, and MAYBE the Flex is confused about which network to use. I know that both times I( redid the WiFi I had to use the SECOND lusting for my house since the first said the Password was incorrect. Anyway, other than that, I've had no issues. And if I figure out what is causing this I'll post another update.
title: This is my favorite Echo yet !

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Terry D
content: I bought this for my bathroom because I wanted to listen to music while in the shower.  I figured as cheap as it is who cares if it shorts out after awhile.  So far though, despite my fiance' taking 45 minute 8000 degree showers, it has held up just fine.  The volume is a little low, as can be expected based on its size.  And the voice recognition seems to be a bit more challenging than with the regular echo dots.  I find myself screaming at it more than I usually have to scream at these devices.  In the end though it usually works pretty well.  For the price, definitely glad to have it for the bathroom.  It'd probably be a good thing to have in the garage too as long as you weren't using power tools.
title: Works pretty well, volume not great - voice recognition not great either.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: GBarrington
content: This was not life-changing, merely darned good. I've read the reviews others have posted, both positive and negative, and I haven't experienced the negative.  It is true that the tiny speaker is not music quality, but when you come right down to it, neither are any of Echo devices except for the largest devices.  It's a speaker about the size of my smallest fingernail, who in their right mind considers that capable of music quality? OTOH, I've found the speaker to be loud, and clear; and the microphone quite capable of picking up my voice anywhere in my kitchen (roughly 12x25 feet opening onto a semi-open great room.  Lots of space for sound to dissipate).  I suspect placement is key with this tiny device, but I've found that to be true with any of the Echo devices for premium performance. Set up was easy, and it went into setup mode as soon as it was plugged in.  In my mind, except for music, this functions as well as the Echo Dot. UPDATE:  I moved my office to a different location just off the family room.  My office is in a room with 2 open doors and is separated by about 40 feet from the first open door.  this Echo flex picks up my voice fine with the doors open.  Now it's true, I have one of those voices that 'carries', but even so, that is still surprisingly good for a tiny echo device with just 2 microphones not aimed directly at my new office.
title: I save 5 stars for a life changing experience.  Updated

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Drumlord29
content: I added another echo device to my collection! I've got every single kind of echo in the market. For obvious reasons, the speaker isn't the best. It is surprisingly smaller than I thought. I use it in my garage for when I close the garage using Alexa. I have the MyQ garage opener which i can open or close with my echo auto in my car. But after I turn off my engine, so does my echo auto. So I have to pull out my phone or manually push the garage opener on the wall. So I plugged it underneath my garage door opener so I can tell Alexa to close or open the garage door from anywhere in my garage without my phone or pushing a button. I don't really intend to use this for playing music. It's really for doing simple Alexa tasks in my garage. It is an echo device that is not meant to look and sound pretty. It's Alexa at its most basic form. Small, no cables, small speaker, and works like any echo device. I believe it's meant for a garage bathroom or hallway if uppity have the night light or motion detector accessory. If you want to play music with it, a bluetooth or wired speaker is highly recommended. Although I had very little expectations with this being that I meant to use it to just open and close my garage, I did notice one negative thing on it. I tried adjusting thre volume from the Alexa app but it switches back to 70% everytime. No idea why. Perhaps there built in speaker is best heard at 70% and if connected to a better speaker, it will allow for a louder volume. I'm going yo have to try that someday. But for now, it's perfect for what I wanted to use it for. If you know what you need it for, don't expect it to be more than that. If you want a better sound, get a dot or something bigger. For simple uses, this will do fine for all your Alexa needs. I may use it for my echo microwave which is currently paired with my echo input connected to a speaker. Don't blame the equipment if you want it to do more than what the hardware can achieve. Be fair to the gadget on what it is capable of doing.
title: Small, not for music, great for basic Alexa

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: TexasDude
content: This shouldn’t be an issue but it actually is and is why I took away a star. These pick up voice and respond much faster than my normal echos and echo dots (latest generations). This is a problem because I bought these for the times when I’m not really close enough to the main echos and wanted to not have to yell (What I call “filler” echos). BUT when I’m trying to talk to a closer Regular echo these pick me up too fast and from far away so they sometimes get what I’m saying wrong or they are not the specific device I was trying to control (for like music etc) USB port is pretty sweet. I have one in my bathroom that I use for a phone charge. One in the hallway that I have the motion hooked up to. And one in another hallway with the light on it for a night light and notification light. The accessory attachments respond quite fast and consistently. People comment on music sounding bad... well duh! The product specifically says these are not meant for music. I’ve actually found them useful in hallways when I have multi room music going and then the flex has low volume for vocals while passing through hallways to the next room. It’s quite pleasant.
title: It’s actually a problem that these can hear and respond better than normal echos

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: BD
content: I love the idea of the echo flex! We have Sonos throughout our house, and don't need to play music on our echo devices. So the echo dot has worked very nicely. However it was bulky and unattractive plugged in to the walls. The flex seemed like the perfect solution, so I bought one... and was disappointed. The size was great! Exactly what I thought it would be. But then I tried using it... It is very quiet! I have 4 small children at home and so there's always some noise happening... This echo would not work well in any kind of main room in my house because of how quiet it is. So, I moved it to the baby's room, but was still disappointed... I can be sitting right next to it and it won't wake to Alexa... I'll have to repeat to get it to respond. I'll bet they make some improvements and the next generation will be better.
title: Meh... Wait for the next generation

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Scott Andrews
content: I bought this to replace my first generation echo do hanging in the outlet in my bathroom. I mainly use this unit for morning news while getting reading in the morning.  The sound quality, in regards to volume, is terrible. With the sound turned all the way up and standing within 2 feet of the Flex, I can barely hear Alexa. I can only imagine how useless the Flex is in a larger room.
title: Sound sucks

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Planet PuertoRico
content: Its very small, alexa sounds like a chipmunk, the attachments are nice but the audio should have been a priority as its the main way of interaction and the first thing you notice, any chance of using the usb port for a better internal speaker attachment? it comes with an aux output for an audio system and bluetooth connectivity for expanded audio options. It's sold as a smart speaker but it just sounds really, really cheep.
title: Small / the audio quality sounds terrible

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: D. Newton
content: REVISED TO 5 stars: One of the latest updates established connectivity and functionality, and it now works exactly as expected. It’s a small speaker, and thus won’t provide anything but minimal sound, nor is it designed to. Understand this beforehand and you won’t be disappointed like so many others who didn’t think through what it was designed for. If you need great sound/music quality, then other Echos are designed for that. So far, the Alexa app hasn’t been able to see/recognize/connect to the Flex, no matter what I do. I’ll box it up and wait a couple of months for an update to fix this issue. I have 14 other Alexa units in total, so this was just a purchase out of curiosity, not necessity.
title: Understand the niche for this, and why the speaker is small, and you will be happy.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: J. Hall
content: I'm so surprised Amazon brought this to market. I have almost every echo device and this one does not live up to the others The sound quality was that of a bad transistor radio. I get the idea of the thing but if it doesn't have good sound quality,  I'm not interested.
title: Save your money!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Rafael
content: UPDATE: After having it for almost a year I been having problems where it disconnects often and sometimes won't respond all the time I can tell it to turn off the light but then tell it to do something else like ask the time and it seems confused, won't answer, but then the next day it does. I lked it for the motion thing but just going to get a regular dot for the garage. I have this in my garage and works perfectly when I'm working there and want to turn on lights I have connected to a smart plug. Also if I want to know the weather or if I have a question in general works great. I can play music on it but it's not great for sound, but I don't think that was the intent for this. If your buying it for higher quality sound get a Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa. Or pair it up with a Bluetooth speaker or use the 3.5 mm audio jack and hook it to your stereo. I did the drop in with an echo dot in the house and it worked great. I could hear them clearly and they could hear me, which is nice if someone needs me they can drop in on the garage. I also have a camera in the garage so I can also see and now talk to whoever is there. Overall I'm happy with it. Oh and if the LED is flashing a yellowish color it's the way it notifies you you have a notification. Found that out when The one I have in the house was also flashing indicating I have a notification.
title: UPDATE:..... Nice little Device, works perfectly as intended.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: kreardon
content: I bought four of these so I could communicate with my family throughout the house. The speaker is so terrible everyone keeps repeating "what?" Sending them back
title: Horrible sound

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Valag
content: The Flex is a great option if you don't like having cords dragging across surfaces. It does everything a regular Echo or Echo Dot can do. and It's actually smaller than I expected. Only occupies the lower plug without blocking the top one. Great for kitchen and bathroom, or anywhere that has above-counter-level plugs. Produces enough sound that I can hear it while in the shower, but, the speaker quality leaves a lot to be desired. I wasn't expecting top-notch, Bose-quality sound from this small of a device, but Alexa sounds like she's talking to me through a Solo cup. So I guess this won't replace any of my other Echo devices for playing music, but it's certainly good enough for listening to the news and weather while getting ready for work.
title: The Echo device that won't Flex your wallet.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: KT - Six Eight Tall
content: We are here to pump up this review! Amazon Flex? More like Amazon Flabby... Ya! This device is so puny that it must go back to the gym to earn it's name! Here is our loser friend to explain why such a flabby device can only lift one star.... <clears throat> Mmmm k. As avid Amazon smart product users, we purchased the Flex based on it's small design form (in that it would occupy the least amount of space and be a perfect kitchen addition to keep our counters open). On this front it is perfect. Speaking in the kitchen, the Echo Dot Second Generation in our living room was actually picking up our voices better than the Flex which was in the same room. To Echo* what other reviewers have said, the sound on this device is tinny and distracting. Considering most smart phones can generate, the small footprint of the Flex isn't a great excuse in 2020 for skimping on sound to this extent. With commands and recipes is was displeasing but with music it was downright distracting. Imagine an old building doorway intercom speaker as an upgrade to this and you get what I mean. I'm guessing the positive reviews are mainly concerned with the small footprint which again, is excellent but even at a discount we had to return this and the accompanying motion sensor in favor of mounting another Echo speaker in our kitchen. Here's hoping Amazon invests just a tiny bit more on the quality of the speaker and microphone array though for future generations of this product because this first gen Flex was an absolute miss for our household. * puns provided free of charge for this unbiased loser review
title: Did someone say Flex?

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Barbara Black
content: I have an Echo and an Echo Show, both of which are great. I ordered this for my kitchen because you can plug it in and not waste counter space. Unfortunately the sound quality is terrible-sounds like a cheap AM radio
title: Sound quality is terrible

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Nobody777
content: What can I say?  It's an Echo device.  It does the job perfectly and I love it...  This is probably one of the easiest Echo devices to setup.  I also like its small form factor and I am currently using it in my garage to control lights and the garage door, and to drop in to chat with my wife in the house on occasion.  The device works flawlessly and I am happy with my purchase and certainly can recommend this device. My only real complaint is with the sound level...  There are no volume controls, just a default setting, which is not very loud.  It's functional and if you're standing close enough in proximity, you can hear it and it gets the job done, but I do wish it was louder.  I never expected this device to be great for anything other than basic Echo functions (which is why I bought it - to control smart devices in the garage), so I wasn't expecting great audio quality...  That having been said, a little bit more volume would have been appreciated.  For that, and that only, I have to knock off a star and give it only one star for volume control because there isn't any.  Sound quality is okay.  I can hear Alexa speaking clearly and she responds perfectly, so the two microphones work well, but since the volume is so quiet, I have to knock off a couple of stars for sound quality.  For the device to be adequately functional, it does need audio... even if it's crappy audio, it should be louder than it is. The one saving grace here is that you can plug in an external speaker (and I presume Bluetooth connections work also) so it's not a total loss here.  There are alternative options that can make the slight negatives here seem unimportant.  I have a decent Bluetooth speaker I use for music when out in the garage, so I'll just pair it up and problem solved. All-in-all, great little device that fits the budget, sets up easily, has a small form factor, and does the job.  Hard to complain about that.
title: Performs well, setup is easy, good price. Not enough volume.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Matthew F.
content: When I first saw this, I thought, what a great idea! A small little "Alexa" to put in the kitchen, so that my Wife doesn't have to yell at the "Alexa" in the living room. I was super excited when this went on sale for $15, so I ordered one. I plugged it in, configured it and figured I was good to go. On first use, I could BARELY hear it. I though... ohhh, the volume must be all the way down. Well.... looking at the app, it was at 70%. So I turned it up to 100%. It really didn't get that much better. I mean, it's a small device, so I wasn't expecting booming sound... but the room has to be completely silent in order to hear it. My phone has a tiny little speaker and it's way louder and clearer than the Flex. In a last ditch effort, we hooked up a bluetooth speaker to it and had to power it off the USB. Having that wire and the speaker sitting next to it completely defeats the purpose of it's small form factor. I might as well just have gotten a dot.
title: The sound quality is horrible.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Raj Chantilly
content: I have reviewed the day I got it and was very much excited and have commented as  " Convenient to move as needed. Still needs improvement". but after 3 months of use and cannot return it with all kind of issue, I felt I need re-review based on my experience. Pros - very much convenient to pull and put into any outlets. Look and shape is perfect. Cons - you will be lucky if you get it work, the first 3 months it was ok without any connection issues, at the same time the sound quality is the first Marconi Radio, so good enough for commands - Alexa turn on a light.  On April 23,2020 they had a software upgrade and after that I was unable to connect to them, I called the customer service almost 5 times and each time they tried the next day it was unable to connect. Finally they refunded me $20.00 but they are not in a mood to understand the root cause, I have been using Echo since the first version came in 2015 and that works perfectly. I have 6 different models of Echo including the auto. I also have request them that if they can downgrade the software so it works, but they were not willing to listen.  I'm trying to get a mesh wifi, may be that can improve the signal as they were asking me to reset all the time.  My final conclusion, pls stay away with this model as both the connectivity and the sound quality are very poor. Rather get a Echo Dot or other Echo models.
title: Lucky if it works....

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: KULANI
content: Aloha! We truly like this product immensely. Easy to install. Super quick to connect to other Alexas. Takes up very little room.  The only con is that the volume could be a little higher. Purchased 2 and considering 2 more. Kids enjoy their Flexs in their rooms. Wonderfully affordable so each room that does not have an Echo or Show can use Alexa Flex. 6-yr old absolutely tickled with hers, asks Flex to read her Audible books and to play bedtime lullabies. My next 2 Flexs will come with night lights (sold separately). Highly recommend this product and suggest to purchase more than one. Mahalo.
title: GREAT PRODUCT TO PLACE IN EVERY ROOM OF YOUR HOME

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: J. Mullen
content: I bought this Flex for use in a utility/laundry room, a place where I do not listen to music, etc. As soon as I plugged the Flex into the wall outlet, it connected to my wifi and essentially installed itself. It is definitely the easiest-to-install Echo device in my network, which includes the original Echo, several Dots, and a host of Alexa-enabled devices. The only difficulty I have encountered is that the Flex's microphone seems more sensitive than the other Echo devices', and sometimes it responds to commands intended for a device in another space. Of course, this is not a serious problem, just an observation. I am very, very happy with the Flex, and I plan to obtain another. Also, I have now added the smart night light device (which plugs directly into the Flex), and it was just as easy to install and to use. Very Happy!
title: Easiest Echo Ever

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kitchen Mouse
content: We have too many Echo devices, by some folks’ standards — a Spot in two bedrooms, a Dot in another bedroom and a Dot in the garage, and a Show.  The show was originally in the kitchen. It was used to check calendars, add to shopping and to-dos etc.  I found the allrecipes skill to be useless, which is why I bought it initially. So I replaced it with the Flex. I was immediately dismayed by how frequently it did not respond and misunderstood me. None of the others have this difficulty. So I put the Show back in the kitchen and moved the Flex to my living room and plugged in a long Apple-compatible charging cable. That turned out to be a great idea because I can charge and use my iPad in the morning as I plow through email and read the e-edition of my local paper. I do use it to turn on my TV, but it doesn’t hear clearly enough to do much else, especially with background noise. I had to cover the mic on my hallway-located Ecobee because when ever I talk to any of my Echo devices, the Ecobee would butt in. The Flex seems to be fairly capable other than you need to yell at it. I don’t recommend it unless you like yelling at inanimate objects.
title: This device is hard of hearing!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: B. Castro
content: A little bit of background first. i previously owned a google nest device and it worked great... for 1 day. after i had set it up, i unplugged it to move it, and it never wanted to connect to my wifi or the app ever again. no help from tech support or the actual device. I just got this tiny echo device yesterday, and am very impressed! i was concerned about connectivity because of my previous nest experience. but so far after unplugging it several times and left off over night, it reconnects all on it's own. good start! i was able to connect it to my amazon music, pandora, and i heart music accounts with very little effort. I haven't tried to connect a bluetooth speaker yet, but it seems to not be that difficult. the device is very responsive, alexa surprised me with some lil bits of humor and side comments/conversations and politeness (spooky).  she walked me thru the music app connections, and made helpful suggestions. the google nest never did any of this. the size of this device is really small (2 decks of cards?). so keep in mind, if you plan on using it for listening to really good music, get a really good speaker to go with it. or, connect it to your stereo system. on it's own, the sound is very much like a transistor radio, and probably will not be good in a large room. which is fine if you just need basics. i've been able to listen to music fine without an additional speaker while taking a shower, and Alexa can hear me fine as well. since i can't give half stars (amazon, please fix that), i gave it 4 stars (4.5 stars) because i'd like a male voice called Alex. Also, it seems it will not connect with my google smart tv. i'll assume that's because google is competition. over all, i like it a lot. so much, i bought another the next day - 1 for the bathroom, and one for the bedroom. well worth the $9.99. buy a bunch and give them away as stocking stuffers at that price. enjoy!
title: Alexa, help me write this review!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Gary Fisher
content: I now own two of these incredibly useful Echo / Alexa Flex devices, and will likely add more in the future. Requiring no cable, no adapter, and no hanger, the Flex simply plugs into any available AC outlet and begins to work. Setup, if you don't receive it pre-paired to your Amazon account, is accomplished just as with other Echo devices. The Privacy and Action buttons on the front panel function like those on other Echoes, and the Flex will respond to all the usual Echo commands. While the speaker is far from Hi-Fi quality, it's perfectly adequate for the spoken word and can give you the news, weather, time, notifications, etc. perfectly well, and at least AM Radio-quality music. The Flex can control lights, appliances, etc. by voice command exactly like other Echoes. On the bottom of the Flex you'll find a full-size USB socket. While handy for charging a phone, etc., this connector is particularly intended to be used with Echo Flex accessories, of which there are currently two, a "night light" and a motion sensor. I own neither of these at this time, but Amazon's information indicates the motion sensor could be used, for example, to initiate a "welcome" sequence when someone walks by, or to turn on lights or perform other functions when it senses motion, without impacting other Alexa functions. The "night light" can be remotely set to an of a variety of colors, perhaps for aesthetics or possibly as a color-coded warning or alert scheme. Once again, the accessories are not required, and so far I haven't justified a need for them. But I'm working on it. 😉 I own a fairly large number of Echo devices, most of which could be used interchangeably. My Flex devices are the only ones in the house which are uniquely suited to their task and could not be replaced by one of the others with no additional work (such as mounting) being required.
title: The Handy "Utility" Echo

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: The Photo Guy
content: The speaker is so bad it is almost unusable. Hard to understand even talk radio. All the available adjustments on the Alexa app including the equalizer do not help. The microphone does not sound good when used for announcements. No volume control, you need to use your phone in the Alexa app to change volume or speak a volume number from 1 to 10.  This is so far away from the quality of the Echo Dot it is hard to believe it is made by the same company. If you need to hang an echo on the wall, get a 2nd generation echo dot and one of the available third-party hangers. This is the first Amazon device I am disappointed in.
title: Sounds terrible, returned it

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Deebs
content: I bought the flex for my basement. I'm older and the laundry is in the basement.  I'm always afraid some day I'll fall down those steep stairs so I try to remember to take my cell with me.  While this will NOT call 911 for you, I can ask it to call my son or daughter if I'm home alone and fall.  Problem is the sound quality.  The outlet is on a far wall, so while it does recognize my voice nicely, I can't hear the response very well as the speaker is very poor for an older person or if there is any other noise.  Hence the lower rating.  I've ordered a dot to replace it and will move this one elsewhere.  Setup - because it was already linked to my Amazon account I did nothing but plug it in, pull the app up on my phone, selected the device and wow it connected!  Nothing else to do!!!!
title: Poor sound, easiest setup ever!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Nicholas H
content: I bought the Flex for my kitchen and I'm very disappointed with it. So straight to the point... 1) Terrible microphone. Unless you're in a quiet room, the device has a lot of trouble understanding me. I have to repeat my commands slower and more loudly, but when I do that, the echo dot in my bedroom upstairs and down the hall responds to me instead. It's basically impossible to use when other people are speaking in the same room. I have to ask everyone to be quiet while I ask Alexa a question. It has come to the point where it's almost a joke if she actually hears me correctly. I don't have this problem with the echo dot. 2) Similarly, unless you're in a quiet room, you can barely hear the response--not just because of its very low max volume, but because the sound quality is terrible--something like a typical kids talking doll toy. 3) This goes for all echo's, getting a Bluetooth speaker connected is painful to say the least. The device name usually doesn't show up so you're guessing at which is the correct device when only the device code is displayed. It also does not reconnect to the Bluetooth speaker automatically and cannot reconnect to a previously connected device through voice command. The idea of telling Alexa to "play music on my Bluetooth speaker" is just a fantasy. You'll have to go through the Alexa app and reconnect manually each time--by which time, you might as well just stream your music from your phone to your Bluetooth speaker instead. 4) When connected to Bluetooth, the volume changes back to level 5 constantly, so you have to keep asking Alexa to go back to volume 10. At level 5, it's barely audible so you might not realize it's connected unless the room is dead silent. Overall, the Flex is virtually useless because it simply doesn't understand me or I can't understand it most of the time (and I mean really MOST of the time) whereas I have no issues with my Dot devices which can understand me in a crowded room even with music playing. In my opinion, the Echo Flex might only be a reasonable solution for a small bathroom although I'd warn you about it still getting your questions wrong if you have the faucet or shower running. Otherwise, I highly recommend getting the Dot instead.
title: Nearly useless unless you're in a very quiet room

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Rabid Ron
content: So far this has been one of the best echo products Amazon has produced.  We use in the kitchen to assist in cooking.  Controlling lights etc is a  breeze along with setting the "Guard" feature when leaving home. Having the add on devices is a big plus to expand it's capabilities. What should be added is a way to utilize both the motion detector and nightlight at the same time by plugging the nightlight into the motion detector. It is going to be an interesting expansion capability if more add on devices are developed. I am already considering a few more to cover the basement, among other places.  As purely a voive control device this ranks as number One in my book.
title: Great way to expand voice control to small spaces.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: 🥇Customer
content: I purchased an Echo Flex plus the companion smart night light to replace what I had in a small bathroom and free up a socket.  In the bathroom I had an Echo Dot 3rd gen in an outlet hanger, plus I had a nightlight plugged into an Amazon Smart Plug.  So, both electrical sockets were used and there was a lot of hardware hanging off the electrical outlet (see pics).  The Flex is perfect for my needs.  It’s much more compact even with the night light (smaller is good, Amazon!) and the second outlet is wide open. Comparison: —Sound:  The Flex sound (both quality and volume) is not as good as the Dot’s.  To me, it’s good enough in order to have a more compact dual device.  Plus my Dot’s sound quality was partially muffled by the prongs on the outlet hanger.  I have Dots in most of the bedrooms and would not replace them with a Flex.  But for the bathroom, the Flex is good. —Light:  The Flex night light is not as bright as the one I had.  Both lights allegedly have 6 LED chips, but my old one is definitely way brighter.  However, the Flex light can be dimmed and turned a few different colors.  There are people around here who like asking Alexa to change the color. —Heat:  The Flex definitely runs very warm just sitting in the socket. —Alexa:  Her pickup of your commands is slow.  You need to be facing her for her to pick you up.  If you speak to her from the side, you may have to raise your voice for her to recognize that you’re speaking to her.  I suppose the acoustics of the room play a role, but that is not an issue when using other Echo devices.  In addition, there seems to be a lag in responsiveness.  For instance, if a song is playing and you ask her to stop playing, sometimes the song continues playing a few seconds as it fades out, or it plays in the background as Alexa is answering a question.  I don’t notice that phenomenon on my other Echo devices. —Looks:  It’s not the most attractive looking device.  Though it looks a lot better than what was there. —Set-up:  Fairly easy.  In my case, I used a Fire tablet for the set-up.  Since my router has MAC filtering enabled, once the Flex showed in the Alexa app list of devices, I got the Flex MAC address and went to my PC to add it to my router settings.  Then, on my Fire tablet, I had to switch to the temporary Amazon WiFi for the set-up.  Good to go from there.
title: This is a great device for where being compact counts

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Deandra
content: I don't hate it enough to send it back but I like my echo dot WAY more. I'd buy 400 more echo dots before I buy another echo flex. It's really quiet all the time, even in the middle of the night when everything seems loud, you know? It doesn't listen to me a lot of the time, so I'll be in the kitchen screaming "ALEXA PLAY SPOTIFY!" that the dot will hear me 3 rooms away from where it is. I can't be as cool as I'd like showing off all my Alexas because this one is insubordinate. But it looks really nice and small, so at least there's that.
title: Just get an Echo Dot.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Jamie Lee Sanders
content: I got one of these to put in the outlet outside of my bathroom to activate the lights on the way in because the switch is in a very impractical place. You have to go all the way inside the bathroom and shut the door to reach it which ranges from mildly annoying in the daytime to very frustrating at night when it's too dark for that sort of nonsense. Alexa Flex could not hear us at least half the time. We'd walk into a dark bathroom, step back and tell her again, walk into dark bathroom again, then go back and lean down to yell at her to turn on the bathroom lights and she still didn't do it every time. Luckily, I already have two dots or I wouldn't have had any faith at all in alexa. I put a dot in the living room about ten feet further away from the bathroom than the flex is, and when we tell the flex to turn on the bathroom lights, the dot actually picks it up and gets the light instead. I finally moved the flex to the kitchen where I had the dot and it seems to do a little better since it's now closer to our face instead of by the floor. I bought her to get the bathroom lights but now she gets the kitchen and entrance lights. I would only recommend the flex if it's truly going to be in a small space where it will be sure to hear you. I have one by my bed as well and she doesn't respond as well as I'd like there either. I would suggest getting the dot if you're able.
title: Only for small spaces

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: avgcustomer
content: This is a convenient device to have, it brings Alexa to more areas in the home. I got it with the nightlight attachment which is great because I have it set to turn on and off automatically at my bathroom sink. My issue is not with the tinny sound through the speakers because I don't really use it to listen to audio, the problem is that the lower quality seems to have carried over to the microphones as well. I frequently have issues with the Echo Flex understanding the commands I'm giving it, and I'm constantly having to tell Alexa to cancel or outright ripping it out of the socket while she's going through the incorrect script. It's especially worse at night when I'm repeatedly having to re-issue commands to turn on my bathroom lights at a dimmed setting and she's initializing burglary detection or looking for a nearby restaurant. I've resorted to carrying my smartphone with me more often so I can just issue commands through the Alexa app. This is in contrast to the Echo Dot which I rarely have issues giving commands to, it has twice as many speakers (4 vs 2 in the Flex) and it sounds better so I'm assuming the microphones must be better to. Do I recommend that you purchase an Echo Flex? Possibly if you need it to use Alexa infrequently in an odd location, but for something as frequent as controlling your bathroom lighting you might want to opt for something with better voice recognition.
title: Too much compromise on quality

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Eric McCann
content: I picked two of these up to mess around with, one with the night light attachment. These were pre-set by Amazon before delivery, so I can't speak to how easy or hard they are to set up - from experience this tends to be quick and painless, though. Brief review on the night light attachment - it's slick and integrates well, and seems to be secure. You can tweak the light color, and yes, it detects low light just fine. It does what it is supposed to and looks like part of the Echo Flex. I see reviews with people complaining about the sound from the speaker. If you're expecting awesome sound from a tiny little speaker, be realistic - this is fine for telling you what the weather's like if you ask, or if you see a notification or other basic information. Playing music... maybe if you want to recreate the early days of radio. It does not do most music justice on its own - but I'm not knocking it for that because (a) that's not what I bought it for and (b) it would be ridiculous to expect it to. If you want to put this somewhere and play music, it *can* pair with a bluetooth speaker (and does come with a speaker out.) Use those, or look into something like an Echo Dot. I am being realistic with the sound quality rating at three stars, though. Fine for notifications or voice. Awful for music. This does take up one of your plugs. It's low enough the other is free (assuming, obviously, you put it on the lower outlet.) This is one thing I'd like to see adjusted - having an outlet passthrough would be nice, though not strictly needed. Perhaps even turning it into a smartplug as well. I'd like to see more accessories for this. The only ones I can see are the night light and motion sensor. Something as simple as a clock to hang off the bottom. A speaker, for those wanting something slightly better without a second device (or someplace to mount a dot.) Maybe a small camera for helping do things like baby monitoring. I think there's potential in this device that's not being used.
title: Works for what it's designed for, could use a tweak or two.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: TnT
content: Only been using it for a few days but so far it's been working great for my application, I'm extremely happy with the product!  In my house I have a central audio system that has built in speakers in the ceiling of all the rooms which is hardwired to a single Echo Dot. So adding these Flex units to rooms that are out of earshot of the main Echo Dot, for example the garage or upstairs bathroom, it's something like adding additional microphones.  I can speak a command and everything plays normal out of the central system as if I'm speaking to the main Echo Dot. People that are complaining about the internal speaker sounding lousy, it says in the description over and over these aren't intended alone for music. After set up the internal speaker is not really used. It will give acknowledgement tones from it but everything else plays to the "preferred speaker"  which you designate within the Alexa app. Adding additional Echo dots with probably accomplish the same thing but this does it in a super compact clean simple plug in module with no loose wires. I haven't tried the motion or the night light optional devices for this but I plan to pick them up
title: It's like adding "extra ears" to Alexa 👍

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: RoboTech
content: First off, the product description SPECIFICALLY STATES that it is not made for music. It is NOT a replacement for an Echo Dot as far as sound quality goes. I am not going to due the product a disservice by giving it a 1-star rating for that reason alone, like other have. I also own several Dot's attached to wall mounts. They are in areas that are clean and dust free, whereas the Flex can be hooked up in a dusty garage or shed without worrying about the speaker cloth getting torn, dirty or moldy. The Flex can be just wiped off with a damp cloth. Even with the Dots on sale, the total cost with a good wall mount is at least $35. The Flex is replacing my Echo Inputs and a couple of my Dots. No cords or mounting worries and about the same price as the Input. I bought the Flex to use in the garage connected to a stereo system and also in a hallway with the night light plug-in. The Flex is the perfect solution and a lot cheaper than a Dot w/wall mount configuration in tight spots where you are not going to use the internal speaker anyhow. Plus, the added benefit of a USB port on the bottom to charge your phone, plug in a night light, or to power a set of USB speakers. As for the microphones, I am not sure why people are reporting that the microphones don't work well. All (3) of my Flex pick up my voice just fine from across the room. Just because the Flex has only 2 microphones, doesn't mean as much as you'd think. The DOT is usually mounted flat on a table and needs all 6 mics to pick up your voice from all angles. The FLEX on the other hand, is plugged into a wall and only has to pick up your voice from a much narrower angle. I have found that the microphones on the DOT can get "confused" when mounted vertically on the wall. The blue ring on the Dot that lights up when activated, has a brighter spot on the ring that corresponds with the direction of your voice. Sometimes you will see the ring on the Dot "spinning" as it picks up your voice bouncing all over the place. The 2 mics on the Flex are better suited for wall mounting. More is not always better. Realistically, nothing is perfect and sure, they could have put a bigger speaker in it. A larger speaker most certainly would have increased the price and made it physically larger. People would then be complaining about that. For me, I am glad is has a speaker for audible Alexa responses at least. In summary, the Flex is not perfect, but for specific purposes and for the price it can't be beat as long as you are not expecting to use it for music (or in a noisy environment) using the built in speaker.
title: Perfect solution for using in a tight space connected to another speaker system.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Jerry
content: I purchased this Echo Flex for a problem area in my house.  I have a staircase leading upstairs to a hallway between the bedrooms.  I have smart bulbs throughout my house including the hallway/staircase.  The problem: If I needed to go in the hall/staircase, I would have to remember to tell Alexa to turn on the light before I entered, or it would be me yelling to Alexa to “turn on the hall light”.  Half the time, she did not hear or understand me as I don’t believe Echo Dots were designed to respond well to yelling from a distance. With the Echo Flex, I simply plugged it into an existing hall power socket after setup.  I now can control the hall/stairway lights in my normal voice.  No more yelling! Some features I like: • Flex costs less than a Dot.  Yes, Flex does not have as good of a speaker, or microphone as a Dot, but I don’t need a great speaker where I have it located and the microphone that is in the Flex works great in the hall/staircase. • Flex is built to hang from a wall socket.  I don’t need a table, nor do I need to buy a hook to hang it from the socket. • Flex does everything voice-wise that my echo Dots do, it can control my smart lights, my smart thermostat, any smart devices I have hooked to my Dots, I cam make and receive announcements, etc.  It is simply a scaled down version of the Dot. If you already own Echoes and/or Dots, Cubes, etc and need better voice coverage in a somewhat enclosed area of your home, the Echo Flex is the perfect add-on.  It appears that this situation is exactly what Flex was designed for.  I give the Echo Flex a very firm 5 stars!
title: Perfect for enclosed problem areas of the home.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: En Yu
content: I only started using devices like echo dot or Alexa recently. It started 2018 Black Friday echo sale I believe. Only started using it properly spring 2019. I began to realize how helpful it can be. Alarms, lists, music, orders, time, weather, news, topic look up, definitions & so much more. Then I discovered the smart bulbs which are really helpful. I don't have to stumble around to turn on my lamp anymore. Then I discovered the smart plugs which I mostly use for starting kitchen appliances. When I got an email about this being on a 50% off sale, I took the leap to get another area in my home Alexa friendly. I knew that the speaker would not be very loud after reading the introduction but we have a sound bar that can be linked to it when we need it to be louder. Setting it up was easy peasy with the Alexa App. I've also learnt how to 'intercom' between Echos so another discovery! I also love that its plug in so no wires & we save table/counter space. All in all, an ultra affordable voice assist device to add to your home!
title: Easy Peasy to Setup

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Gil
content: I have many Alexa devices around my home and some are better then others but this one appears to be deaf, I find myself yelling at it from 2 feet away! And forget about it if there's noise like music in the room, it dose fit nicely where it's at though and the echo it replaced was a bit to big for the spot so what I did was add a remote which is like a hearing aid for the flex. Now I use the remote and can whisper to the flex and it responds quickly. I would rather it be hands free but maybe they'll update the firmware to address this major flaw. Does everything great now. Update, It's morning and went to turn flex on with remote and nothing! It shows as paired but remote will not wake it. After pairing again it's working, will see how long it works! Don't buy this as it's not ready for the public if it's deaf! Okay, appears batteries had low power so put in a fresh pair and problem solved. Still should not need remote as it's supposed to work out of the box. Needs work!
title: Deaf device!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Suzannah
content: I have tons of Alexa devices, this is by far my least favorite. It seems I have to reconnect the device every other week and I’ve had it less than a year. I’ve only had to do that once to my Echo Show in the two years I’ve had it. I bought the Flex for my laundry room so I can continue to hear my audiobook as I do my chores moving from room to room while the book plays on the everywhere group. This DARN hunk of plastic is always suddenly disconnected from the group and from my network every other week while all my other devices continue working perfectly fine. I didn’t even mind the tinny/weak speaker it has because I listen to books mostly but without a connection it just sucks up my electricity until I can stop what I’m doing and reset/reconnect everything. This product is a dud in my opinion. Oh, and my laundry room is near my router and not on the other side of my house. I have Alexa devices much further away that work fine.
title: I’m about to chuck this piece of plastic

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Lynn
content: First I'm not sure why I bought this. I own several Alexa devices. Echo dots, firestick, firetv etc. I don't know why I thought the usb ports would work by Alexa but they don't. That's fine I misunderstood and jumped the gun. I havent bought any of the only two accessories that exist for the flex so far. I may or may wait and see if Amazon comes up with more or better accessories for the flex. I use this is my kitchen right now away from the Dots. The sound quality is mediocre at best but that doesnt bother me. My 3rd G Dot has great sound. I am actually ok with the sub par sound because late at night if I ask Alexa anything my dots volume is usually up pretty loud and startles me. I don't think to ask her to turn her vol down first and whisper mode never works right for me. The flex is quiet lacking any bass sound or EQ features. At 3 am I can appreciate the mono sound not startling me or disturbing anyone in the house. My most negative opinion is that several times Alexa failed to respond to me after multiple request repeating ALEXA ALEXA. Nada. Most of those times happened while I was listening to music through the flex. I had to unplug it each time to stop the music. A few other times while silent the flex just didn't activate at all. I have debated returning it.  But I haven't and I decided to hold off and see if any of the accessories make it worth the buy.
title: Not for music enthusiast. Mono sound, Not the most responsive Alexa device.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Bernard Eisenfeld
content: I've had the epiphany and converted to "smart" devices. It started with a little Echo dot in my home office. The wee little thing was so cute and hardly took any space up.  I used it mostly for time of day and weather reports. Then I got the big boy stud Echo Studio for the home gym and used if for great sounding music. Pair up two for great sounding stereo for under 500 bucks! Then I came the Echo Plus for the kitchen and it too sounds good but not as good as the Studio behemoth. The gates were breached and a flood of plugs, switches and dimmers followed. The capper is the petite cutie Echo Flex. Plug it into any outlet and turn on the hot water pump in the garage from the second floor master bedroom by saying, Alexa pump on. Tired of saying Alexa, chang the wake word to Echo. Then add a Flex to every room. I'm hooked. I need help!
title: Buy one. Heck, buy three or four!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Outlaw Reviews
content: I have 8 Alexa devices around the house and this is the only one that has issues with voice recognition Speaker sound quality is also horrible. Do not buy. Not a well-thought out product.
title: Horrible product. Do not recommend

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Tex75
content: I'm a big fan of the Echo Dot but I don't like looking at the untidy cord. When I saw this for pre-order I thought it would work great in the kitchen to replace the Dot. Set-up was simple and it looks decent enough but the audio... The sound is the equivalent to the worst AM radio. The volume can't be adjusted from the Flex, you have to go into the app, which is not at all convenient. Attempting to raise the volume is frustrating because although you may set it to 100%, when you reopen the app it is at 70%. No matter how many times you try to leave it at 100%, and boy did I try, it always turns itself back down. Needless to say, with the poor quality speaker and the inability to turn up the volume, if I am making any kind of noise in the kitchen (running water, frying food, running the microwave) it drowns out the Flex to the point I can't understand what is being said. I have no choice but to bring the Dot back to the kitchen and move the Flex to a quieter part of the house where it will see less use. The idea was good but poorly done. My hope is that Amazon will learn from this mistake and give us a much-improved Flex 2.
title: Not a good alternative for the Dot

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kail Withers
content: It was starting to get expensive being an informant, but these little guys are cheap enough to put in every room. No longer do I need to awkwardly move the conversation to another room when the juicy intel starts flowing. Snitching on my friends has never been so easy. Sometimes when I am trying to come off as cool I play a little  Beyonce, this thing doesn’t have the speaker to project her range, let alone the whole Destinys Child. But I didn’t buy it for that, I have the good ones for that, plus if you pair it with a good bluetooth speaker like a Samsung sound bar with a subwoofer then it doesn’t even matter. But I tell you what, this thing picks up the quietest conversations.
title: Being a snitch just got affordable

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Brad K
content: My apartment is 100% Alexa enabled, lights, ac/heat, door lock.  Lights are either Phillips hue(most reliable I’ve found) or Wemo switches.  (Pain to install, but non tech people can use them) I needed a night light for my bathroom and also had been trying to figure out if an echo do would look weird and operate on a vanity (always getting wet from the sink.... ) my closet is off my bathroom, so I was having issues with my other echos understanding me.  This plus the nightlight plugin solved both issues.  It’s voice recognition seems to be almost on par with a dot.  The speaker is plain and simple abysmal.  I’m sure they did this on purpose.  I’m not just talking about it’s not able to play music, but even it’s Alexa voice sounds like it coming from a tin can tied to a string. But it’s voice recognition is good. I have an echo show and spot sitting in drawer because they sucked at voice recognition, the spot is by far the best product on the market and it seems like this does a good job too.  But it’s only good as a control interface where you need extra coverage and one of its extra interfaces would be useful.  Bathroom + nightlight is an excellent example of this.
title: Great for specific purposes

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: FYI
content: I have an Echo, 3 Echo Dots, an Echo Input, and now this Echo Flex.  The Flex was given to me as a gift.  Overall, it really doesn't do anything for me.  Positive aspects may be that it plugs directly into an electrical outlet eliminating the need for a power cord, and possibly future accessories that hopefully are forthcoming.  Currently the two accessories that are available don't offer any wow factor for me.  Negative aspects:  not visually attractive; the speaker is basically useless because of low volume it generates and lack of tone.  It would probably function better pairing with a blue tooth speaker.  I would recommend spending a little more for the Echo Dot -- or maybe even the Echo Input.  The Dot has decent sound reproduction as a stand alone, and the Input looks better than the Flex but does require a power cable and some sort of extension speaker.  I think the Flex was a "swing and a miss" for Echo devices. Update:  spoke with an Amazon rep this morning following my posted review (great customer service Amazon!).  After elaborating on my opinion regarding the Flex, the rep provided me with some suggestions as to how to get better sound performance out of it.  I followed the advice and was able to produce better sound (volume and tone).  With that, I would change my rating on the device to 2 stars.  I am still of the opinion that this is not one of Amazon's better products, but I understand it will fit the needs of other customers.  I will continue to try the Flex in different locations to see if I can make it more usable for me.
title: Lackluster Device

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Liss
content: Overall, I like this Echo Flex, but it was an absolute bear to install.  It made me re-enter my wifi password so many times I nearly gave up.  A few weeks later my phone informed me there was a new Echo available to install--and sure enough, this little Echo Flex had somehow dropped out of my devices.  I fought valiantly for over an hour to reinstall it--it literally kept telling me my network password was wrong.  I got online to search for help and found nothing that worked. I thought I was going to have to return it.  I was about ready to turn off my wifi/network and endure the slow cycle of everything coming back up, but I decided--what the hell--why don't I at least try unplugging and replugging the confounded Flex. And that fixed it.  I didn't even have to reinstall.  It was suddenly back in its rightful place in my devices.  Shrug. The sound quality is minimal, but it serves its purpose in my little utility room.  I use it with a motion sensor so I don't have to say or do anything to have the lights come on when I'm toting a big load of laundry into the room.  It's a reasonable little machine.  I do think, however, that it's much harder to install (because it seems to have trouble grasping onto wifi signal) and a bit more glitchy than the other Echo devices.  Still, I don't regret its purchase.
title: Pretty good, but with a few glitches

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Vlarr
content: It's exactly what I expected. I wanted a little Alexa for my bathroom to listen to music while showering and also because it seems that it's when I'm there that I remember all the things in my to do and grocery lists, so it seemed necessary. The Echo flex is small, and I dont have a lot of counter space left in there, so it fits right in. She hears me while I'm in the shower, although I do have to talk a little loud, but *for me*, the volume is perfect. I was hesitant of getting it because many reviewers were saying that it has a little voice that can't be heard over the shower, but for me that's not the case. disclaimer: I so have VERY good hearing, I can hear my husband whispering his thoughts In the next room... ok. Back to Echo flex. She does have a tiny voice" as a reviewer said, but to me it's loud enough that if I'm in the room and I have a reminder in the bathroom, I hear it perfectly. All in all, it's exactly what it is suppossed to be and I would get another one for the other bathroom if it becomes necessary. In summary, if you have good hearing it's probably ok for you.
title: Not too quiet (for me!)

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: enterbackspace
content: These are great! Initially bought two for use in the bathroom (household announcements) and next to the front door (Alexa Guard). Have since ordered four more. Why? To give as gifts to the over 65 family members! Set up is simple (think plug-and-play). They take up very little space. Able to make voice calls from the device via simple commands. Meaning, if someone falls in the bathroom and can’t get up without assistance they have options. They can say “Alexa, call (husband/wife/child)” and Alexa will call phone number associated with the individual requested. Another option is to say, “Alexa announce I fell in the bathroom and need help”. Alexa with respond by announcing, to each Amazon device in the house, “I fell in the . . .”. No need to carry something in your hands or wear something around your neck. This device won’t cause the over 65s to feel old or inept but rather is just a cool thing that can read them the paper or tell the weather while they’re getting dressed in the morning and be there to help out too if something goes wrong. So awesome.
title: Added Safety!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Clintre
content: First off, it is not a great device for music or hi-fi sound. Do I wish that it was better? Sure, but I did not expect that and it works great for what we wanted it for. What we like... It is great for those tight spaces and areas that you want the convenience of Alexa, but don't have counter/table space. The fact that it is a small plug-in device makes it great for those areas. While the sound could certainly be better, it does do great for doing routines or dropping into other rooms in our house. We have one in our bathroom to listen to news and run routines, while getting ready. What is not to like? Pretty much just the sound quality. It would have been nice if they could have gotten close to even a cheap smartphone's speaker sound quality. Don't understand why it is not at least a little better. Overall... We have bought a second one to use in another area that has limited space. It is definitely better than the bulky plug mounts for regular Echo Dots, unless you need/desire sound quality for music.
title: Works great for limited types of uses

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: imnorm
content: The Flex is perfect in form - well thought out, easy to install in hallways, etc without the need for cords hanging anywhere.  The voice-recognition in the Flex works really well - sometimes better than a full-size Echo.  I see two "misses" and if I'm being totally honest I can't say the one is the Flex or the motion sensor attachment. Issue #1 - the motion sensor attachment goes wonky every few weeks and the way I've found to fix it is to unplug the Flex from the wall, wait a few seconds and plug it back in. Issue #2 - I didn't expect the speaker to be used for music and so I have the Flex set to play music on another Echo device in an adjacent room.  That's great, but what I needs is the ability to tell the Flex to use that other Echo for music, but let the Flex handle other verbal output so that if I play music it goes to another Echo with decent sounding speaker, but if I just ask Alexa a question or give her a command, the response should come from the Flex whose speaker is sufficient for verbal responses.
title: Perfect form, could use a bit of help in function

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Grady Richardson
content: Okay, I didn’t need this. I already had Echos in almost every room in my house. But when Amazon put this on sale for $10, I figured that for 10 bucks, I’d find a use for it. I put it in my hallway, just so in the 10 seconds or so that I’m walking from the family room (which has a Show) to the guest bedroom ( which has my original Echo) and the bathroom (which has a ceiling mounted Dot) door happens to be closed, I can still use Alexa without raising my voice. Maybe my wife is right. Maybe I do need help. Anyway, as to the merits of the device itself. It’s a really nice piece of technology. It’s ridiculously easy to set up. I plugged it in, got my iPad, opened the Alexa app and Alexa announced that my device was ready. Seriously. I didn’t have to do anything at all. I did rename it and put it in a hallway group, but that’s it. It’s an Echo. That is, it does everything any other Echo does, just smaller and cheaper. The only drawback is its tiny speaker, but no one is going to buy this to listen to music on (or they shouldn’t, anyway). I’d probably have put it in the garage for Smart Home control, except that’s where I keep my Tap. Highly recommended for places where you want voice control and don’t care about sound quality.
title: The littlest Echo.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: S. Johannsen
content: I have a couple of these, one with a sensor module, one with a nightlight module. There are some places that don't really have a good place for an Echo, but could stand some of the convenience. I have the one with the sensor in a walk-in pantry. The sensor allows the light to be turned on when  entering with hands full, which happens frequently in a pantry. The Echo functions let you drop in somewhere to have someone add something to a grocery list, or you could add to a digital list directly, when you see something is running low. The one with the night light is in a 'guest' bathroom. (Kids have left home, so now it's a guest bathroom). The nightlight works like any other and is good for guests to find their way without flipping on bright lights. The Echo part lets you broadcast, hey, we need TP in the guest bathroom, without straining your voice. I had one in the garage for a while, announcing 'Someone's in the garage', based on the sensor. Could easily be used to trigger lights in the garage as well. So there are some use cases that can benefit from these. I'd stick to places that have outlets a bit higher than the normal ft above floor ones. The microphones on these are fine, the speakers are not to loud, and certainly not intended for music. As a cheap intercom, they are great.
title: Useful in some specific cases

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: James T.
content: The new Echo Flex does exactly what it is supposed to do, which is why I bought one.  Amazon came up with this small Echo device to give people the ability to add an Alexa enabled device literally anywhere you have an electrical outlet, so that you can control all your smart devices with your voice, and make your life a bit easier. For this, I gave it 5 stars.  I wanted to have an Alexa enabled device in my kitchen so I could turn some lights on and off with my voice when I am busy cooking, or to ask for food measurement conversions, to set timers for cooking different things, and to also answer the phone when my hands are messy.  All of these things it does, and does perfectly. I also bought it to have voice activation of all my music, which I have it play over my WiFi speakers that I have in all the rooms of my house.  Again, for this, it does that function perfectly.  My kitchen is the loudest room in the house, especially at meal times!  And the very tiny speaker built into the Echo Flex gets drowned out very quickly when people are talking, exhaust fans are going, and spoons and other utensils are banging against pots and pans.  So to try to listen to music on the actual Echo Flex is never going to happen.  Not even in a quiet room. That is not the Echo Flex's intention.  People are bashing the sound that comes out of the Echo Flex as being really poor quality.  And it is, compared to larger Echo devices like the Echo Dot and regular Echo.  If you want to listen to music using the speaker in an Echo device, you have to buy a larger one!  You buy the Echo Flex to expand the areas of your house/garage/basement that you want to have voice control in! My favorite feature of the Echo Flex is that it plugs directly into an electrical outlet with the male prongs on the back of it.  It does not use a long cable like all the other Echo devices.  This puts it up and out of the way of other things you normally have on your counter tops or shelves.  By getting it up off your workspace you don't have to worry about knocking it off or damaging it by accident. Another feature the Echo Flex has is that there is a USB port on the bottom of it that you can connect USB enabled devices to.  There are night lights you can plug into it, and there is even a motion sensor you can plug into it that you can use to program WiFi enabled lights to turn on and off when you enter a dark room.  That is pretty cool. Overall, the Echo Flex is a great little Alexa enabled device that expands the areas that you want voice control of all your WiFi and smart items.  Think of it as your assistant, or helper.  You tell it what to do, and it does it.  For that, it works great.  Using it as your only means of listening to music?  No way.  It is not designed for that, and you will be disappointed in the sound quality.  You want a larger Echo device for that. But if you buy it for what it is, and what it was made to do, you will love it, and it will make your life easier and more enjoyable. Jim
title: Does exactly what it is supposed to do.  No more, no less!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: P. Smith
content: Like the other Alexa devices, the Flex was easy to setup and get running. It’s biggest drawback is the quality of sound from the speaker. If you’re expecting the quality of sound of the Echo Show or Dots you will be disappointed. The speaker sounds like one out of a cheesy transistor radio. However, if you are looking for just a basic Alexa device to get the weather, time, set/get reminders or alarms, but no music, then the ease of placement in a variety of nooks and crannies with a power outlet where it can be placed will be appealing. What I’ve done with it is place it in an entry hallway with the optional motion detector. I created a routine with the options set for Monday-Friday starting at around 5:30-7pm, if motion is detected, it will greet me, announce across all my Alexa devices that I’m home to alert the family, turns on the various downstairs lights (if they aren’t on already) where I have on smart plugs and bulbs. Then I set it it to wait for 60 minutes before it will trigger this routine so it won’t go off every time I pass by from that point on. You could also create another routine that every day of the week, after the time when you go to bed til you wake up, if motion is detected send a custom alert to any Alexa device in your home (such as your bedroom) and then set off a buzzer/alarm on the Flex device this serving as a poor man’s alarm system.
