If you're expecting awesome sound from a tiny little speaker, be realistic - this is fine for telling you what the weather's like if you ask, or if you see a notification or other basic information. Playing music... maybe if you want to recreate the early days of radio. It does not do most music justice on its own - but I'm not knocking it for that because (a) that's not what I bought it for and (b) it would be ridiculous to expect it to. If you want to put this somewhere and play music, it *can* pair with a bluetooth speaker (and does come with a speaker out.) Use those, or look into something like an Echo Dot. I am being realistic with the sound quality rating at three stars, though. Fine for notifications or voice. Awful for music. This does take up one of your plugs. It's low enough the other is free (assuming, obviously, you put it on the lower outlet.) This is one thing I'd like to see adjusted - having an outlet passthrough would be nice, though not strictly needed. Perhaps even turning it into a smartplug as well. I'd like to see more accessories for this. The only ones I can see are the night light and motion sensor. Something as simple as a clock to hang off the bottom. A speaker, for those wanting something slightly better without a second device (or someplace to mount a dot.) Maybe a small camera for helping do things like baby monitoring. I think there's potential in this device that's not being used.
title: Works for what it's designed for, could use a tweak or two.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: TnT
content: Only been using it for a few days but so far it's been working great for my application, I'm extremely happy with the product!  In my house I have a central audio system that has built in speakers in the ceiling of all the rooms which is hardwired to a single Echo Dot. So adding these Flex units to rooms that are out of earshot of the main Echo Dot, for example the garage or upstairs bathroom, it's something like adding additional microphones.  I can speak a command and everything plays normal out of the central system as if I'm speaking to the main Echo Dot. People that are complaining about the internal speaker sounding lousy, it says in the description over and over these aren't intended alone for music. After set up the internal speaker is not really used. It will give acknowledgement tones from it but everything else plays to the "preferred speaker"  which you designate within the Alexa app. Adding additional Echo dots with probably accomplish the same thing but this does it in a super compact clean simple plug in module with no loose wires. I haven't tried the motion or the night light optional devices for this but I plan to pick them up
title: It's like adding "extra ears" to Alexa 👍

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Mike
content: So initially I thought this would be a great addition to my garage as a smart speaker. I thought to my self it’s small, doesn’t need a cable or a desk to be displayed on (mounts directly to the  wall vía it’s plug), and it should fill the garage with some smart tech easily, only that wasn’t exactly the case. My main gripe is with the sound quality, it’s awful and basically ruined the product (Especially since it’s all about voice activated features and doesn’t have a screen). Alexa sounds hollow/awful and music sounds even worse. There is limited to no bass and the mids/highs aren’t anywhere (good) to be found either. That being said, there also aren’t enough redeeming qualities to make this a well rated product. Yes I did pay a decent price on it (Amazon had a 50% off sale around the end of 2019) and it has a built in USB port on the bottom. So then you’d think that’s cool it was cheap and there is a port (basically giving you an extra charge outlet for a phone or something) and yeah I’d agree with that thought process, then I noticed the two official add ons for the USB port (a night light and a motion sensor) are half the MSRP of the unit and honestly should have just been built in (with a better speaker). Then, and only then, would this have been a 4 star or better product but instead it’s barely a 3, more like a 2 star product if you paid full price. I’d say wait for gen two or another steep discount before you buy this thing.
title: Half baked “smart” speaker...

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: TBS
content: The concept of this is nice but the sound quality is not good at all. I wanted it for my office to listen to music but it's not great for that. Echo Dot has much better sound quality.
title: Nice Concept but Lacks Decent Sound Quality

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ashley N Ward
content: I was SUPER excited to have an echo I could easily plug into my bathroom wall. I even ordered this a month in advance. However, when they say "mini smart speaker" they really mean MINI smart speaker. Even when you do the "level 11" secret volume, these are still so quiet. I have a regular echo dot (3rd gen) and the volume is perfect. However, I have a vent fan in my bathroom that turns on when I turn on the light and I can barely hear it over the fan. I'd expect that if the volume was at a 5 or 6, but a 10 or 11? The sound quality is even a bit fuzzy despite being so quiet. I don't expect it to be as loud as a normal echo, but it's big enough they could have added better speakers. Very disappointing.
title: Way too quiet

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ashley
content: I think these might be a little expensive for what you’re getting. I mean it’s a nice concept but the sound quality is horrible. I expected it from a small device but at least it’s nice to put in a small space. I put them in the bathroom so I can make announcements that dinner is ready or something like that. I’m planning on playing some Christmas music on it for the bathroom which I think would be nice with the decorations I have in there. Definitely wouldn’t be able to hear the music if you were in the shower tho. If you could, it would be very faint.
title: They’re okay but not necessary.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: capo
content: I have Echo devices of one kind or another in every room and have had others that I’ve decided to let go (original Echo and Echo Auto). They’ve all performed their smarthome duties acceptably well. My biggest complaint across the board is sound quality. Alexa always sounds like she’s talking to you from underneath a pile of pillows. Bass? Sure, on the Echo Show, at least. Treble? Nada. Sure, you can use the app’s “equalizer”... but it’d take an oscilloscope to detect the minuscule difference that makes in the sound quality. I’d given up on getting any more devices... until I saw a review of the Flex on Paul Hibbert’s YouTube channel... he liked it, but said (I think) that it sounded ‘trebly’. Trebly?! That’s a magic word to my ears. I ordered one up and found that it indeed sounds ‘trebly’ (call it tinny of you like) but who cares? Who seriously listens to music on these tiny little devices anyway?! I can understand what Alexa says now - all the plosives are there. I still wonder why Amazon can’t tune the rest of the Alexa enabled devices for better higher frequency clarity.
title: Treble! Hooray, I can understand Alexa now!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Consumer Advocate
content: Compared to Echo Dots, the Echo Flex is a good space-saving idea but the microphone(s) were unreliable and the speaker was a joke so the 1st one I ordered was returned. NOW in 2020 ... I decided to give Echo Flex a 2nd chance. Either they improved the device considerably or the first one was defective because the 2nd one is WORKING LIKE A CHAMP!
title: Nice case design improved microphone & speaker ?

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: JC Fazzone
content: As with all Amazon product, it is better to wait for next generation products as with time the products do get better. This item is a disappointment with sound and volume control. While it fits in small spaces, it’s worth while to buy an Echo Dot with mounting bracket. Very disappointed that 14.99 is necessary to purchase the night light. Not recommending this product.☹️
title: Will pay to wait

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Jason H.
content: After writing this review and rating it 2 stars, I received a call from Amazon.  They wanted to tell me that the speaker on the Echo Flex is not meant to be the main audio source.  The intent of the design is to use Bluetooth to connect to an external speaker.  This would, of course, resolve my concern with the sound quality, so I increased the rating to 3, or okay.  But in thinking about the Flex alone, I don't think I would rate it as good or great, because it has limited appeal without additional investment. I'm not particularly fond of the idea of adding a speaker just to have this device, because I could buy a Dot instead.  However, I concede that there are niches where this functionality and price savings would be useful.  For example, after thinking about it further, I realized that I could connect it to my Bluetooth enabled treadmill and have Alexa right up front for music or any other questions I might have without having to mount an Echo Dot on the wall.  The Flex plugs in securely to a wall socket and leaves the second outlet open.  It's not heavy and doesn't sag like some two-pronged, heavy transformers do. Installing this was a simple as unpacking it and plugging it in.  It had already been integrated into my account and the WiFi login was automatic. Notifications cause the LED to blink brightly.  It's much harder to ignore it, when you already know what the notification is.  You have to ask, what's my notification, in order to clear it. The sound is like a cell phone's speakerphone, and is hard to listen to.  This device would go best in a garage or out of the house, where you might want access to announcements or activating guards, but not where you want to hear it every day.  (edit:  you are expected to connect to a Bluetooth speaker by design) Giving plenty of space in front of the device helps with communication.  Putting it in a tight space can cause echoes or chirps and clicks that interfere with it.
title: For someplace you won't need to listen to it every day.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Sandra Knight
content: I have had this for a year and it works flawlessly.  I use it for alarm time setting when I am cooking, playing music, weather, getting correct time and date, movie listing, etc.  I find it play music loud enough for me.  I have it in my living room, and can hear it in bathroom, bedroom and kitchen.  Of course I live in a 1000 sq ft. apartment and the sound is very good.  When I am talking on phone, the other party on line says they can hear it very plainly so it is loud.  Don't know why the comments say its bad for hearing, must have an extra large house.  Right now its so loud that I have to have Alexa turn it down some.  I also have the night light attachment and it comes on automatically at dark and in the morning I have to tell Alexa to turn off light.  And that works perfectly also. I just love it. You will too.
title: Wonderful Little Alexa

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ella Belle
content: I just got my Echo Flex - Plug-in smart speaker with Alexa this morning and I'm already totally in LOVE with it! With it I also bought that "Made for Amazon" THIRDREALITY Smart Night-Light for Echo Flex, and I love it too! I had been wanting to put an Echo Dot in a very tiny bathroom, but I was trying to figure out how, since I have no counter space and didn't want to use up my last outlet. Then, along comes this Echo-Flex thingy, so I decided to give it a try. I've been super delighted with it all morning long! I love how it just plugs right into an outlet and is totally out of my way but still basically does most of what the echo Dots do. I had a regular nightlight in the room that took up an outlet socket, so this new Smart Nigh-Light was a great solution because it plugs right into the bottom of the Echo Flex, so just the Echo-Flex is using that 1 outlet now. It's so cool too because I can ask Alexa to change the lights colors! I've bought 4 of the Echo Dots for my home and I am in love with all of them. This Echo-Flex is just a smaller version that is so perfect for small bathrooms, laundry rooms and basically anywhere else where you just don't have counter or table space for an Echo Dot. I also love how easy it is to set these devices up! Just be sure the little box below the "Add to Cart" and "Buy Now" buttons is checked "Link to my Amazon account to simplify setup"! It really does simplify the set-up wonderfully! Anyway, I am totally loving this new Echo-Flex so much and I already have ideas of getting some more of them for other tiny places around my home that I had not considered before. These things are just so helpful AND so fun! UPDATE 08/16/2020: I've now bought 4 of these echo Flexes with the nightlights. One for the laundry room, one for my Kitchen and 2 for my small bathrooms. I use these every day and they have become indispensable!  Sure, the sound is not super great for music, but the fact that these are not stealing any counter space is paramount for me. I have other Echo's in other rooms for music anyway. I love these things! UPDATE 10/13/2020: I am STILL in love with these cool little Echo Flex gadgets!  I use them many times daily! A great size for small rooms like Bathrooms, laundry rooms, store rooms, mud rooms, garage, even out in our woodshed! I happily got more today on Prime Day! Thank you Amazon!
title: Awesome Alexa Solution For Small Rooms!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Carmchocolate2
content: Nice addition to the Echo family.  Perfect size for the bathroom without having to deal with cords.  You can't expect big sound from this small device, but it serves its purpose.  I am able to set reminders,  timers, alarms,  and add things to my shopping lists while getting ready.
title: Perfect size for small places

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Mr Huskey
content: It is very bulky robbing room from other items you might want to plug in.  The speaker quality sucks.  No where near as good as the Echo plus speaker.  Playing music on the Flex's built in speaker sounds like listening to an old transistor pocket radio.  It does pair easily to my blue tooth speakers which sound really good. Motion detection works, but is almost useless until the Amazon Alexa app matures a bit more.  Settings in the app are too cumbersome to want to use at the moment.  Controlling a light seems easy enough, but I wanted it to turn on a Wyze switched outlet.  I had to create a new group... assign the Wyze switch to it... create a routine to turn on the group.  There was no skill that let me just turn on/off the switch without creating the group first.  Seemed like way more hassle than it should have been. The night light seems nice, but I haven't spent much time playing with it yet.  I just picked the first color that was bright enough to fill the room.  Too bad you can't have motion sensing and the night light in one module.  I really only want the night light to turn on when I step out of bed in the middle of the night.
title: A very minimalistic  Echo device

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Tech Gospel
content: I wasn't expecting it to be as loud as the Dot 3 or anything... but I was hoping at least as loud as the 2nd gen Dot. It was barely audible plugged next to the bathroom sink standing 2 feet away... even less so in the shower. Although you can plug an external speaker to it, it defeats the purpose of it. It could work if you prefer using an external speaker (3.5mm will support drop-in, bluetooth will not) and just want to plug something in the wall and not worry about cables. But overall, I was disappointed and just swapped it for another Dot.
title: Barely audible

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: D. Coral
content: I set up this cute little Echo Flex + Motion Sensor in the garage.  It was easy to add Routines in the Alexa app to turn On and Off the WeMo light switch for the garage light.  I had this automation ready to go in about 5 minutes.  It’s real nice to have the garage light come on automatically whenever I open the garage door.  I also set it to turn off the light after no motion is detected for 1 hour (choose any time period). You can also have the motion sensor activate an Echo device to speak a custom phrase, give a news flash briefing, traffic report, play music, etc. There is a setting to specify the time when the motion sensor should perform the Routine (anytime, or between a certain time period) and to suppress a repeat of the Routine for a configurable time period so it won’t keep doing the same thing every time there is motion, if you don’t want it to.  For example you can have it give you the traffic report or news briefing when you enter the bathroom in the morning but only if the motion happens between 6-8am. This is super useful — after trying out the first one, I’m going to buy a few more to play with around the house.
title: Motion Sensor is Handy!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Spyder2014
content: If you are looking for a quality speaker to listen to music while you are in the bathroom or kitchen... pay a little extra and get an echo dot. The flex is perfect if you want to add another echo device for the sake of controlling smart home devices, taking advantage of the guardian functionality or for the occasional drop in. You also get the added functionality of either a motion sensor or night light with the available accessories. We replaced our bathroom night light with the flex and it is great! The light accessory gives off more light than our old night light and my wife loves the different colors you can choose due to the built in rgb LEDs. I tested the drop in feature as well and it was loud and clear while talking to my wife in the next room. I highly recommend the flex if you want an additional echo device in a bathroom, kitchen or spare room and don't want the hassle of hiding the cables, or if you want to add motion sensor triggers or a night light to a room.
title: Perfect... for what it is!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Debra T
content: I am in the midst of setting up an Alexa eco-system in my home. I have a Fire TV, first generation Echo, Fire Tablet, Echo Show 5, and several smart plugs. I wanted an Alexa-enabled device in my bedroom to do the "basics" ... respond to my voice commands ... and to turn the smart plugs on my bedroom lamps on and off. So I got an Echo Flex. I set it up in less than a minute, and soon it was turning my lamps on and off, telling me the time, answering my silly questions and telling me jokes! People, this is how technology should work. The world would be a much techno-friendly place if all technology was this easy to set up. I didn't get this for the sound quality of an Echo or for the screen time of an Echo Show. If I had wanted those features in my bedroom, I would have spent more more money to get them. I can never figure out why people buy an entry level product here on Amazon that does "the basics" and then give it a bad review when it doesn't do everything the "cadillac version" does. Sheesh. What I love about this product: --It's a great price. --It does what it's intended to do. --It can be enhanced with a bluetooth speaker, a nightlight or a motion detector. --It's out of the way. --It only takes up one outlet. The other one is still available for use. --You can plug in a USB device to it, like a smartphone, to charge it. What I dislike about this product: --Nothing. Because it does what I bought it to do. In my book, Amazon gets big kudos for giving buyers options for different features and price points of their Alexa product line.
title: Works great for its intended purpose!!!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Amodeus1971
content: Besides the speaker being small and sounding like garbage the Flex has gotten better over time. The motion sensor I have come to like now that I have adapted to it and they have seemed to iron out some of the problems. My main problem now is they limited the use of it because they are only allowing you to own two of these with the motion sensor per Amazon account unless you have a business account. No other explanation besides they tried to get me to sign up for an Amazon business account. I have one in my bathroom and wanted to put two in my kitchen are because there are two entrances and I wanted to make my lights fully motion-controlled in my kitchen. I can do this to a point with Wyze Sense but I don't want any more cameras inside my living space than I need to have, which are the two on my rear windows as the other security cameras are all outside. This imitation severely limits the usefulness of this product.
title: Rewritten review

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Michael
content: The worst Amazon Echo Product to date. Would never recommend. Really wanted to have this, but sound quality is terrible, microphone is horrible
title: Horrible

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: K. Gagliano
content: I am thrilled that I can have another layer of safety in my home. Super simple to set up...plug and go pretty much. No wires yay! Speaker is so so but I didn't purchase for listening to music, I have my Echo and Dot for that.  I'm a big fan of the  "Ask my buddy" app. and now god forbid I should fall while in the shower I can call for help. Already tested with my family/neighbors with shower running and worked like a charm. Love the added dawn to dusk nightlight.  So extremely happy to have found this product. Worth every penny!  Tks Alexa lol!!!
title: "Flex" great addition to Echo's!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: thornhillatthemovies.com
content: I'm not thrilled with the Echo Flex. I have an Echo and love that, I have a bunch of plugs connected to it, and control the lights throughout our small apartment with it. I have had some difficulty getting other smart plugs to communicate and connect with Alexa and our Echo. So, when I saw the Echo Flex on Amazon, I initially thought it was a smart plug with Alexa built in. It isn't. And that's my mistake. Our apartment is very small, so I plugged the Echo Flex into the wall (it really looks like a multi-plug you plug into a regular outlet) and connected it. A few days before, I got a wall clock made by Citizen and connected it to the Echo. With the Echo Flex plugged in, and connected, all of the voice recognition was going through the Flex and the Smart Clock no longer did the countdown with a timer, as it did with the Echo. I unplugged the Echo Flex. The smart clock worked fine. I think if you have a bigger house and more rooms to cover, using the Echo Flex is a good way to get more coverage. But in our small apartment, it isn't necessary. I can control the Echo in our living room, from our bedroom. When the Echo Flex was plugged in, it seemed to recognize my voice well. But the speaker on it reminds me of playing something through a small speaker on a cheap cassette player. Remember those? It is hollow and tinny and would not be a good vehicle for music or other audio. If Amazon could come up with a smart plug directly tied into the Alexa range, I would buy that.
title: Possibly Good For Some Situations... But There Are Problems

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Lenny
content: I have this in my garage, where it's more useful than I expected. I originally got this so that I can turn on the garage light when I come in from the side door (the light switch is at the other side of the garage, near the kitchen entrance). I set up an Alexa routine so that it will turn on the light for a minute, giving me enough time to walk to the other end of the garage to enter the house without tripping over things, before turning itself off. So far that has worked very well. The USB port also turned out to be more useful than I expected. With so many things that recharge from USB these days, such as my bicycle headlights, it's nice to have another charger in the garage. I measured the charging current at 1.6A, I'm not sure if that's the maximum current, or just how much my light draws when recharging, but it is more than I expected. Finally, having it as a plug in form factor saves me the hassle and expense of getting a separate mount for it. Downsides, the speaker is not as good. It specifically says it's not suitable for playing music, but within a few days of using this, Alexa said that I haven't asked it to play music and if I would like to do so. I guess someone didn't program it properly. Finally, the microphone isn't as good as the other Echo devices I have. Even the 1st generation Echo Dot does a better job of recognizing my commands when there's extra noise in the background. Overall, for the price and utility, it deserves 5 stars.
title: Inexpensive device for where you don't need to play music

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Discriminating Buyer
content: I've been putting in echo dots and shows around the house, really to be used as an intercom/announcement system and for control of some smart items.  My parents are elderly and my Mom had a stroke a few years ago so I prefer to have some sort of communication system around that is voice activated (as long as they can speak) in an emergency.  It's also proved handy for them to control lights, view some cctv cams, fans, the air conditioning, etc. I bought the flex used based on the poor reviews that it got, I figured that if they didn't work at least I wasn't out the cost of a new one.  I wanted these for areas where I don't have dots.  Setup was probably easier than any other Echo device I've had.  It apparently uses bluetooth so that has to be turned on on the phone.  I did a test speaking close into the dot and it transmitted to all the other echo devices.  The sound from it isn't that bad, I was expecting some really tinny sound but Alexa sounds much the same as on the other devices.  I haven't tried music on it to see how that sounds but I did make Alexa sing the 20 second wash your hands song and it sounded okay. UPDATE I tried music on it and while it wasn't terrific it wasn't all that bad. I decided to put this in the carport instead up near the ceiling and it definitely is tinny sounding there and not very loud.  I maxed the volume through the app and it still wasn't very loud.  It seems to hear okay though.
title: Better than I expected!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Sharon Clark
content: I bought this for the basement as I am terrified of falling down my cement steps and being unable to get help.  I placed it in the center of the basement in the only available outlet.  Volume goes up to 10, which, unfortunately, is very low for my slightly impaired hearing.  I need to be within a few feet to hear it at all and ideally within a few inches to understand.  I have an echo plus and a couple of dots and have them about halfway because they can be loud.  The flex at full is way too quiet, would never buy another and wouldn't recommend for that reason.  That being said, I really only need it if I fall down the steps and need to call for help.  I have asked the time, etc occasionally from the flex, it does hear me better than I can hear it so I have protection from "I've fallen and can't get up".  Old ladies living alone need inexpensive safety measures and this one is great for that.
title: Works great and gives piece of mind

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Clayton M.
content: I bought this for my mother, who has been looking for a nightlight for her bathroom. Paired with the ThirdReality smart night-light accessory , this lovely little Alexa device gives you peace of mind in areas you can't easily place one of the larger Echo devices with a surprisingly bright adjustable LED lamp. The pictures I've attached show the night-light using the sensor mode - it's off when the lights are on, and turns on when the room gets dark. You can see also that it shows as a controllable light in the Alexa app. There are several colors to pick from and a slider to set brightness; I have it set to 2% here because the bathroom is connected to a bedroom - the light can definitely be much brighter if you want that. === PROS === - Small form factor doesn't take up space. - Plug on the bottom lets you mix and match accessories (night-light, motion sensor, etc). - If you don't want an accessory, use the bottom plug to charge your phone! - Works great with mid-wall plugs like those you find in bathrooms (near the counter) or kitchens (by the sink). - Use a 3.5mm cable or Bluetooth to connect a dedicated speaker for playing music. === CONS === - Audio quality is ok, not meant for music playback using the built-in speaker. Very tempted to buy a couple more of these on sale; I am sure I can find a few more spots in our home that could be introduced to Alexa!
title: Makes a great smart nightlight

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Adrienne Boswell
content: We live in a two-bedroom apartment.  We have an Echo Dot in the living room that shares a table with a Google Home Mini.  Then I have an Echo Dot in my bedroom, and my son has a Google Home Mini in his bedroom.  I also have a Fire Tablet in the kitchen that I use for recipes, music, etc.  There was only one room missing in order to make this apartment fully Amazoned out - the bathroom.  Now, Alexa can hear me no matter where I am in the house, and I really like that. But, besides that, I like having an echo in the bathroom so I know what time it is, so I can listen to music or my morning routine, check the weather, all without having to go into the bedroom or living room.  I know, first world problems, but it works for me. I just answered a question about if you can use the Flex to make phone calls.  Yes, you can.  It's not a Bose speaker quality, but, I have to say, it's actually better than my phone sometimes is. So, I can chat on the phone when I'm getting ready, too.  Nice. I really like that it's so small and plugs right into the wall outlet.  It doesn't take up much space, and especially in the bathroom where counter space is at a premium, it's great that it can live on the wall and not the counter. I recommend the Flex if you want Alexa coverage all over your home.  These little ones are inexpensive, small and unobtrusive. Great product.
title: Great new member of the family

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: A fan from Meriden, CT
content: Its has been a while since I wrote an Amazon Review, but I felt I had to for this. It is a WONDERFUL Product ! I already had a 1st Gen Echo Dot that is setup in my living room. And after some early trepidations, everyone in my family uses it. I got a smart light to go along with it & that is great as well. So when I recently got a couple more smart lights to set up in my Office, I needed another echo to control that. And that's why I got the Flex. My office is in the basement so using the Echo in the living room to control the lights isn't ideal. All I needed was something small, so the flex is a perfect fit. I just tucked it into a corner by my stereo receiver and plugged it into a short extension cord. Bingo ! Now I have full Alexa capability downstairs. I use it to turn on the lights (I added a smart plug to my desk lamp as well) when I come downstairs to start my day & it can hear me easily from across the room. And while the sound of the on-board speaker isn't great, I plugged it into the Audio Input on my stereo & now it sounds FABULOUS. What else do I need, ? And at only HALF the price of a Dot (and a quarter of the price of a full size Echo) why WOULDN'T you get one ? Thanks for making this, Amazon - it's perfect ! UPDATE: Make that slightly LESS than perfect. Please be aware this may not be the Echo's fault ... BUT I have had to redo the WiFi connection on it TWICE since setting it up. I thought rthat maybe it was an issue witth My Amazon Connectivity in General, but I verified that the Dot in the Living room & my App both work fine - its just the Flex. And its not because the Flex is farther away, its MUCH Closer, The Router is literally NEXT TO where the Flex is installed. And there are no sources of interference nearby that I am aware of. The only thing I can think of is my son does have a WiFi extender set up in the living room, and MAYBE the Flex is confused about which network to use. I know that both times I( redid the WiFi I had to use the SECOND lusting for my house since the first said the Password was incorrect. Anyway, other than that, I've had no issues. And if I figure out what is causing this I'll post another update.
title: This is my favorite Echo yet !

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Terry D
content: I bought this for my bathroom because I wanted to listen to music while in the shower.  I figured as cheap as it is who cares if it shorts out after awhile.  So far though, despite my fiance' taking 45 minute 8000 degree showers, it has held up just fine.  The volume is a little low, as can be expected based on its size.  And the voice recognition seems to be a bit more challenging than with the regular echo dots.  I find myself screaming at it more than I usually have to scream at these devices.  In the end though it usually works pretty well.  For the price, definitely glad to have it for the bathroom.  It'd probably be a good thing to have in the garage too as long as you weren't using power tools.
title: Works pretty well, volume not great - voice recognition not great either.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: GBarrington
content: This was not life-changing, merely darned good. I've read the reviews others have posted, both positive and negative, and I haven't experienced the negative.  It is true that the tiny speaker is not music quality, but when you come right down to it, neither are any of Echo devices except for the largest devices.  It's a speaker about the size of my smallest fingernail, who in their right mind considers that capable of music quality? OTOH, I've found the speaker to be loud, and clear; and the microphone quite capable of picking up my voice anywhere in my kitchen (roughly 12x25 feet opening onto a semi-open great room.  Lots of space for sound to dissipate).  I suspect placement is key with this tiny device, but I've found that to be true with any of the Echo devices for premium performance. Set up was easy, and it went into setup mode as soon as it was plugged in.  In my mind, except for music, this functions as well as the Echo Dot. UPDATE:  I moved my office to a different location just off the family room.  My office is in a room with 2 open doors and is separated by about 40 feet from the first open door.  this Echo flex picks up my voice fine with the doors open.  Now it's true, I have one of those voices that 'carries', but even so, that is still surprisingly good for a tiny echo device with just 2 microphones not aimed directly at my new office.
title: I save 5 stars for a life changing experience.  Updated

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Amanda N.
content: I have the echo flex paired with a Sengled Pulse speaker light bulb in a ceiling can light in my bathroom. As soon as I flip on the light switch where the bulb is, the echo flex automatically connects to the speaker bulb. When playing music to the speaker bulb, then turning off the light switch, the echo flex automatically kicks back over to the flex built in speaker and the music is not interrupted, and vice versa. The built in speaker is great to get weather updates, etc at the start of the day while getting ready in the bathroom.
title: Perfect for a bathroom

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: jon
content: It would be a clever addition to the Echo line if the sound wasn't so terrible.  I didn't expect great sound, but I did expect to be able to hear it.  The volume is so inadequate, that I am returning it. The Echo Dot is a far better choice if small size is your driving force. Sure, you can pair it with a Bluetooth speaker, but that kind of negates the small footprint. If you just need something to control lights or other devices, I suppose it's ok.  But if you want to listen to news or the like, it's inadequate.
title: Low volume hurts this Echo

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kit Clayton
content: The sound quality is far inferior to an Echo or even a Dot.  But, guess what?  This is a Flex, not an Echo or Dot!  One of these is plugged in right next to my home’s intercom, with the stereo jack right into the intercom system.  The horrible Flex speaker is moot, since it feeds directly into the home intercom and associated speakers - which all are far superior to even the echo or Bluetooth speakers.  So, even rooms ,utility/workroom, garage, porches, and decks without an Echo devices now have Alexa.  Check it out - since Flex is right next to intercom, can trigger Alexa through the intercom!  Brilliant, right?  True - not as convenient as just talking (and why there are still 4 echo devices in strategic places throughout the home) but in outdoor and other places (such as garage and work room) where it is not a good idea for an echo, a good way to smart home up everything.  And here I thought intercoms were worthless in this day and age.... I got a second Flex just to - well, flex.  Can plug it in anywhere (screened in outdoor gazebo in summer) on the property for instant voice activated Alexa for when I am too lazy to get up and push an intercom button.... Soooo, this is a great device if used for intended - and advertised clearly on product page - purpose.  You want barely passable music, then get an Echo for five bucks more when they are on sale.  you want a easy p,ug in flexible unit (er, hence the device’s name) for voice activating Alexa - or, in my case to Alexify (yes, “Alexify” is a verb in my world) my whole home intercom system, then this device is perfect.  5 stars - clearly, as I bought another one already, is recommended if used for how it was designed.
title: Outstanding Alexa extension!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Somebody
content: I received two Echo Flex devices today. I'd read all the one-star reviews before ordering, so I was prepared to send them back if they were as awful as some folks say. But when I unboxed them and plugged them into outlets, I was glad to see how quickly and automatically they connected to my wifi. Ready to use in about a minute or less. Yes, those who say the audio is tinny are right. Not at all as good as my Echo Dots, Echo Show, or the original Echo tower. But the two locations where I wanted to put the new devices aren't areas where the quality of the audio matters: living room and bathroom. So far, Alexa has had no problem hearing me, nor have I had trouble hearing her. I even tested the living room one to see if Alexa could hear me when the TV is on. I raised my voice only slightly above conversation-level. No problem. I also heard her despite the TV's audio. I noticed that the Flex in my bathroom sounded louder than the one in the living room, so I put the living room one in the bathroom to compare them. No difference. My guess is that the Flex sounds louder in the bathroom because it's a tiny room, while the living room is considerably larger. Also, I'm closer to the Flex in the bathroom (about 15" when standing at my washbowl) than in my living room where I am across the room from it (about 9'). The one glitch my living room flex has is the volume control. The bathroom's volume is set at 100%, but the living room's volume is stuck at 70%. Now, having said that, it sounds just like the 100% volume on the other Flex. I tried repeatedly to boost the volume to 100%, following the directions in the app to do that, but no luck. I have emailed support to see what I can do to get it to 100%, but truthfully it doesn't matter. As just about everyone says, the Flex is not suitable for listening to music -- but I decided to give it a try. I told Alexa to play Taylor Swift's "Look What You Made Me Do". It was far from good, but it was also nowhere near horrible. All in all, I'm pleased that I decided to replace my clunky Dots which were hanging from the outlet in holders (to keep from having to deal with cords). The Echo Flex is *much* better aesthetically, and it meets my needs.
title: Didn't expect much, but happy with the purchase

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: John Silvia
content: I've installed this in my garage - adds intercom capabilities and kills my old clock-radio. Overall the Echo Flexs' performance has been good.  It has limitations - but those are kind of expected given the packaging and price. Mounted at shoulder level over my toolbench, I'm rather happy with its performance so far.  The microphones aren't as sensitive as the ones in my Echo Dot's, so I have to speak a bit louder. The on-board sound output is weak - very low-fidelity. Definitely meant for low-traffic areas, sounds like a walkie-talkie due to it's tiny speaker. The 3.5mm output drives external speakers without trouble. I'm finding that volume 10 is the line-out volume - leaving you with 100% manual volume control on the external speakers.  I'll be trying it with my old Microsoft subwoofer setup later for kicks. Overall this is a great little Alexa, but I would not purchase this in lieu of it's bigger brothers in most cases. It's sound quality and microphone aren't as good as the larger units, but this can make it perfect in some remote low-traffic areas, or maybe hallways or large closets. Add the motion detector for full coverage. The casing is hard-plastic - it has a more appliance-rugged finish - looking very much more like an ultrasonic vermin repeller than an Internet thing.
title: Great "Low-Fi" Alexa

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: amazon_shopper
content: I like that it's a simple plug-in that sits there; no adapter, no cable, no hassle.  It does everything I need it to and is functionally no different from any other Echo device when it comes to voice commands and responsiveness.  The sound is a bit lacking, but I never considered it my primary source of audio entertainment either.  It's good enough for listening to the weather, news, or anything else not requiring premium sound.  But honestly, the sound quality is no worse than the stock radio in a 1980s K-car, if you know what that is.  The Flex performs well as an additional listening sensor for glass breakage while in Alexa Guard mode and having more sensors also expands your voice control options throughout the house.
title: Great way to expand the Alexa presence in your house.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: R Mountain
content: We are an Alexa household and she’s slowly taking over the place.  We bought the echo Flex like many of you I suspect to go in the bathroom. Alexa works great like it does in all of our other Amazon products and it’s nice to be able to listen to music, get the weather, and even to use it to drop in and tell a kid to get out of there we are going to be late. The only negative is the sound quality.  Yes I wasn’t expecting much for the price but I wanted it to be just a bit better.  Hopefully a future version will add a slightly better speaker. Overall it’s still a good product that we use daily.
title: Almost perfect.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Wills944
content: To start, I have a few technical grumbles about the platform itself but I do enjoy my "Dots" They [1 in the Living Room, 1 in each of the 2 bedrooms] have operated reasonably well, the only technical hickup with them is the occassional device dis-association from a room group..i.e. walk into a room say "turn on the lights" and it responds 'Can't find a device called Lights". So far its about once a week on one of the Dots.. The Flex's haven't had this happen and they've been unplugged and reinserted a few times.. The Flex's appear to only have 2 mic pinholes. I have had a little bit of a time finding placement for the Flex that allows it to pick up audio better. Our 2BR Apartment has laminate floors with the kitchen on one end, the combined entry/dining room acting as a echo chamber, and the carpeted living room and it's Dot at the other end. The kitchen Flex would pick up from the living room and visa versa.. Others have noted the sound "quality" as bad, but in all fairness it is about the same as the speaker function on a cellphone. It's not bassy like the dots, but I have played music while in the bathroom and it is not a bad/horrible experience. It is great to listen to the news while shaving/cleaning up or just waiting.. Once the shower is on though, external speakers would be required. On the positive notes.. The look of the device is demure enough that it blends in without being too "in your face". Hopefully skins will become available. These Flex's, Dots and Shows are great, but I hope more useful devices are in the mix. Maybe a Kitchen Device that includes a barcode scanner for maintaining a real shopping/pantry inventory, with a extension that could perhaps go over the garbage bin to scan out items. It's nice to to be able to voice add items to a list, or have a fridge that questimates usage, but a easy in/out scanner would be fantastic.. I'd also like to see the Prime Video/Music apps accept Alexa commands. I get the reasons behind branded devices, but it would be just as easy to add subroutines into the apps that intergrate commands from the platform. It would be great to have a the ability to simply have apps that can be put on devices for reading news flashes, then a simple "Alexa show me the news on the living room TV" through my android media box... Apps are easier to get to market on devices that are already global.. So hopefully Amazon expands the line in some real useful ways..
title: Good step in the right direction

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Branson Mom living in Chillicothe
content: There are SO MANY things this little device can do.  Initially I bought them exclusively as intercoms, but because I didn't understand the correct way to use them, I rated them a 3*, now that Amazon Flex expert contacted me and spent nearly an hours educating me to the device WOW, and I mean WOW...!!!! Okay it is like an extension to your Alexa or Echo Dot, but it does things I'm not even sure they can do.  These are amazing, and now instead of 2 I'm probably going to have 2 more for downstairs. Be sure to educate yourself on the differences, they can be subtle so if like me you might miss some big pieces of info. One, you can name each differently, so when you 'drop in' (not any other way as I was doing) you can have a conversation with the persons that are at that Flex.  So yes, an intercom.  You can broadcast announcements to every device, or 'drop in' to just one. I now have so many Ring and Amazon devices my house probably should be seen from outerspace, lol.  And I am far from finished.  I want every bulb to be a smart bulb (you gotta try those, omg), I want every room to have a Flex (okay I have 16 rooms, maybe not every room), I already have a plethora of Ring cameras inside and out, but also am trying a different brand that works with Alexa too, but tons less expensive (and Ring truly is not what it use to be). Point being, its good to have security on your house, convenience in your house, and it all tied to one system - Alexa.
title: Buy Alexa only products, and be sure they can interact interchangably, mine ROCK

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Jerry
content: I purchased this Echo Flex for a problem area in my house.  I have a staircase leading upstairs to a hallway between the bedrooms.  I have smart bulbs throughout my house including the hallway/staircase.  The problem: If I needed to go in the hall/staircase, I would have to remember to tell Alexa to turn on the light before I entered, or it would be me yelling to Alexa to “turn on the hall light”.  Half the time, she did not hear or understand me as I don’t believe Echo Dots were designed to respond well to yelling from a distance. With the Echo Flex, I simply plugged it into an existing hall power socket after setup.  I now can control the hall/stairway lights in my normal voice.  No more yelling! Some features I like: • Flex costs less than a Dot.  Yes, Flex does not have as good of a speaker, or microphone as a Dot, but I don’t need a great speaker where I have it located and the microphone that is in the Flex works great in the hall/staircase. • Flex is built to hang from a wall socket.  I don’t need a table, nor do I need to buy a hook to hang it from the socket. • Flex does everything voice-wise that my echo Dots do, it can control my smart lights, my smart thermostat, any smart devices I have hooked to my Dots, I cam make and receive announcements, etc.  It is simply a scaled down version of the Dot. If you already own Echoes and/or Dots, Cubes, etc and need better voice coverage in a somewhat enclosed area of your home, the Echo Flex is the perfect add-on.  It appears that this situation is exactly what Flex was designed for.  I give the Echo Flex a very firm 5 stars!
title: Perfect for enclosed problem areas of the home.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: RoboTech
content: First off, the product description SPECIFICALLY STATES that it is not made for music. It is NOT a replacement for an Echo Dot as far as sound quality goes. I am not going to due the product a disservice by giving it a 1-star rating for that reason alone, like other have. I also own several Dot's attached to wall mounts. They are in areas that are clean and dust free, whereas the Flex can be hooked up in a dusty garage or shed without worrying about the speaker cloth getting torn, dirty or moldy. The Flex can be just wiped off with a damp cloth. Even with the Dots on sale, the total cost with a good wall mount is at least $35. The Flex is replacing my Echo Inputs and a couple of my Dots. No cords or mounting worries and about the same price as the Input. I bought the Flex to use in the garage connected to a stereo system and also in a hallway with the night light plug-in. The Flex is the perfect solution and a lot cheaper than a Dot w/wall mount configuration in tight spots where you are not going to use the internal speaker anyhow. Plus, the added benefit of a USB port on the bottom to charge your phone, plug in a night light, or to power a set of USB speakers. As for the microphones, I am not sure why people are reporting that the microphones don't work well. All (3) of my Flex pick up my voice just fine from across the room. Just because the Flex has only 2 microphones, doesn't mean as much as you'd think. The DOT is usually mounted flat on a table and needs all 6 mics to pick up your voice from all angles. The FLEX on the other hand, is plugged into a wall and only has to pick up your voice from a much narrower angle. I have found that the microphones on the DOT can get "confused" when mounted vertically on the wall. The blue ring on the Dot that lights up when activated, has a brighter spot on the ring that corresponds with the direction of your voice. Sometimes you will see the ring on the Dot "spinning" as it picks up your voice bouncing all over the place. The 2 mics on the Flex are better suited for wall mounting. More is not always better. Realistically, nothing is perfect and sure, they could have put a bigger speaker in it. A larger speaker most certainly would have increased the price and made it physically larger. People would then be complaining about that. For me, I am glad is has a speaker for audible Alexa responses at least. In summary, the Flex is not perfect, but for specific purposes and for the price it can't be beat as long as you are not expecting to use it for music (or in a noisy environment) using the built in speaker.
title: Perfect solution for using in a tight space connected to another speaker system.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Grady Richardson
content: Okay, I didn’t need this. I already had Echos in almost every room in my house. But when Amazon put this on sale for $10, I figured that for 10 bucks, I’d find a use for it. I put it in my hallway, just so in the 10 seconds or so that I’m walking from the family room (which has a Show) to the guest bedroom ( which has my original Echo) and the bathroom (which has a ceiling mounted Dot) door happens to be closed, I can still use Alexa without raising my voice. Maybe my wife is right. Maybe I do need help. Anyway, as to the merits of the device itself. It’s a really nice piece of technology. It’s ridiculously easy to set up. I plugged it in, got my iPad, opened the Alexa app and Alexa announced that my device was ready. Seriously. I didn’t have to do anything at all. I did rename it and put it in a hallway group, but that’s it. It’s an Echo. That is, it does everything any other Echo does, just smaller and cheaper. The only drawback is its tiny speaker, but no one is going to buy this to listen to music on (or they shouldn’t, anyway). I’d probably have put it in the garage for Smart Home control, except that’s where I keep my Tap. Highly recommended for places where you want voice control and don’t care about sound quality.
title: The littlest Echo.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: S. Johannsen
content: I have a couple of these, one with a sensor module, one with a nightlight module. There are some places that don't really have a good place for an Echo, but could stand some of the convenience. I have the one with the sensor in a walk-in pantry. The sensor allows the light to be turned on when  entering with hands full, which happens frequently in a pantry. The Echo functions let you drop in somewhere to have someone add something to a grocery list, or you could add to a digital list directly, when you see something is running low. The one with the night light is in a 'guest' bathroom. (Kids have left home, so now it's a guest bathroom). The nightlight works like any other and is good for guests to find their way without flipping on bright lights. The Echo part lets you broadcast, hey, we need TP in the guest bathroom, without straining your voice. I had one in the garage for a while, announcing 'Someone's in the garage', based on the sensor. Could easily be used to trigger lights in the garage as well. So there are some use cases that can benefit from these. I'd stick to places that have outlets a bit higher than the normal ft above floor ones. The microphones on these are fine, the speakers are not to loud, and certainly not intended for music. As a cheap intercom, they are great.
title: Useful in some specific cases

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: James T.
content: The new Echo Flex does exactly what it is supposed to do, which is why I bought one.  Amazon came up with this small Echo device to give people the ability to add an Alexa enabled device literally anywhere you have an electrical outlet, so that you can control all your smart devices with your voice, and make your life a bit easier. For this, I gave it 5 stars.  I wanted to have an Alexa enabled device in my kitchen so I could turn some lights on and off with my voice when I am busy cooking, or to ask for food measurement conversions, to set timers for cooking different things, and to also answer the phone when my hands are messy.  All of these things it does, and does perfectly. I also bought it to have voice activation of all my music, which I have it play over my WiFi speakers that I have in all the rooms of my house.  Again, for this, it does that function perfectly.  My kitchen is the loudest room in the house, especially at meal times!  And the very tiny speaker built into the Echo Flex gets drowned out very quickly when people are talking, exhaust fans are going, and spoons and other utensils are banging against pots and pans.  So to try to listen to music on the actual Echo Flex is never going to happen.  Not even in a quiet room. That is not the Echo Flex's intention.  People are bashing the sound that comes out of the Echo Flex as being really poor quality.  And it is, compared to larger Echo devices like the Echo Dot and regular Echo.  If you want to listen to music using the speaker in an Echo device, you have to buy a larger one!  You buy the Echo Flex to expand the areas of your house/garage/basement that you want to have voice control in! My favorite feature of the Echo Flex is that it plugs directly into an electrical outlet with the male prongs on the back of it.  It does not use a long cable like all the other Echo devices.  This puts it up and out of the way of other things you normally have on your counter tops or shelves.  By getting it up off your workspace you don't have to worry about knocking it off or damaging it by accident. Another feature the Echo Flex has is that there is a USB port on the bottom of it that you can connect USB enabled devices to.  There are night lights you can plug into it, and there is even a motion sensor you can plug into it that you can use to program WiFi enabled lights to turn on and off when you enter a dark room.  That is pretty cool. Overall, the Echo Flex is a great little Alexa enabled device that expands the areas that you want voice control of all your WiFi and smart items.  Think of it as your assistant, or helper.  You tell it what to do, and it does it.  For that, it works great.  Using it as your only means of listening to music?  No way.  It is not designed for that, and you will be disappointed in the sound quality.  You want a larger Echo device for that. But if you buy it for what it is, and what it was made to do, you will love it, and it will make your life easier and more enjoyable. Jim
title: Does exactly what it is supposed to do.  No more, no less!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: P. Smith
content: Like the other Alexa devices, the Flex was easy to setup and get running. It’s biggest drawback is the quality of sound from the speaker. If you’re expecting the quality of sound of the Echo Show or Dots you will be disappointed. The speaker sounds like one out of a cheesy transistor radio. However, if you are looking for just a basic Alexa device to get the weather, time, set/get reminders or alarms, but no music, then the ease of placement in a variety of nooks and crannies with a power outlet where it can be placed will be appealing. What I’ve done with it is place it in an entry hallway with the optional motion detector. I created a routine with the options set for Monday-Friday starting at around 5:30-7pm, if motion is detected, it will greet me, announce across all my Alexa devices that I’m home to alert the family, turns on the various downstairs lights (if they aren’t on already) where I have on smart plugs and bulbs. Then I set it it to wait for 60 minutes before it will trigger this routine so it won’t go off every time I pass by from that point on. You could also create another routine that every day of the week, after the time when you go to bed til you wake up, if motion is detected send a custom alert to any Alexa device in your home (such as your bedroom) and then set off a buzzer/alarm on the Flex device this serving as a poor man’s alarm system. Of course, if you have any pets wandering around this sort of alarm won’t be very useful. On the just for fun side, I have another routine that is triggered when motion is detected during a certain time period where Alexa will say a random compliment. Yeah I know, totally frivolous, but keeps the kids entertained. The routines you can build with the motion detector have some very well thought out options and actions that work flawlessly. So if you can tolerate the chintzy speaker, the Flex has some good usage possibilities.
title: Good if you set the right expectations

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: D. Sah
content: Love these little guys. When we bought our house, we took out the master for the intercom in our remodeling and I’ve been screaming for my kids ever since. I don’t enjoy screaming. It’s not a huge house but if they have any music going our they are zoning out, talking (loudly is their usual base), I have to yell louder. Although we aren’t an Alexa house, these were on sale during prime day so I thought, wth and bought a couple. The kids love asking Alexa random crap, having her play music (even on the crappy speaker); and hubs and I enjoy dropping in and making announcements unexpectedly. Especially when they aren’t brushing their teeth or doing their distance learning as they’re supposed to be. As an aside, I set up one in their bedroom and they the kid controls I put it on do not disturb. The. Forgot I did this (it takes awhile to figure out all the set ups) and could not get it out of do not disturb through the other more obvious settings. I had to call support, and they couldn’t figure it out. Finally, after a few resets and pretty much giving up, I realized it was out of service until 8 am 2 mornings in a row, I remembered vaguely setting a kid control. So if I went thru the right kid (which was attached to the device) I could remove that schedule.
title: Perfect- using as intercom

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Eric K.
content: The Amazon Flex was on sale super cheap, so I decided to get one.  I thought it would work perfectly in our master bathroom so we could listen to music, the news, or ask Alexa questions when in the shower, bath, or getting ready for work.  Our Amazon Echo is in the living room, which is too far from the bathroom to be able to shout to, and I certainly wouldn't be able to hear it very well. The Flex was easy to set up.  I just plugged it in.  My Alexa app recognized it right away and I just had to follow the simple instructions with a couple of clicks (and inputting my Wi-Fi security code).  You then have to leave your phone within a few feet of the Flex while it's connecting everything. While not very visually appealing as the Echoes and Echo Dots have been getting, the Flex works just as well, as it connects to my main Echo via Wi-Fi.  The sound quality was pretty good, even better than my original Echo Dot from years ago. Why get a Flex instead of an Echo Dot?  For one, it was a lot cheaper at the time I bought since a great deal was going on.  Two, it doesn't need to "sit" anywhere.  It's plugged into an electrical outlet (which we rarely used in the bathroom anyway), so it's not taking up any counter or shelf space.  Three, there are no unsightly cords either.
title: Great Addition to our Echo Family

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: superdogmom
content: I had a Dot connected to a Bose Mini II speaker on my desk.  With a wireless phone charger, desk fan, desk light and task light, definitely needed less clutter.  Got rid of the Dot and plugged this little thing into the wall, then connected it to the speaker with an audio cable.  Perfect.  Alexa is loud and clear and the hockey puck no longer takes up desktop real estate.  I know it could have connected with Bluetooth, but prefer a good old-fashioned, trouble-free 3.5mm audio cable connection because it's one and done.  Liked this little unit so well, I ordered a second one for the garage.  When I work out there, I'll use it with my travel speaker.  Great little unit.
title: Cleared the clutter

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: jessica
content: I really like that this takes up less space by being in the outlet. However, the speaker is horrible. I don’t use my echo (I have a 1st generation dot) much for playing music, so I thought this would be fine. I knew it wasn’t meant to be a speaker, but It is really bad.  Even just for it speaking back to me, it is bad.
title: Space saving but awful speaker.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Rob Howell
content: Based on the reviews and descriptions (and prime day price) I decided to purchase a Flex so that I could add a third party speaker to my speaker group. Unfortunately the sound does not sync up properly with the Echo and Dots that make up the rest of the multi-room group. Testing music directly on the Flex syncs up but on its own this also syncs right if using an aux cable but not when connecting via Bluetooth to a speaker. I tested with two different speakers by different manufacturers but came to the same result.  On the plus side the device itself is louder then expected and can be heard a room over clearly. I wouldn't recommend it over the dot for this purpose but for spoken audio (standup/audio books/pod casts/etc) and normal Alexa usage besides a morning alarm it works fantastically.
title: Good standalone micro speaker but not good for Bluetooth multi-room grouping

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Tex75
content: I'm a big fan of the Echo Dot but I don't like looking at the untidy cord. When I saw this for pre-order I thought it would work great in the kitchen to replace the Dot. Set-up was simple and it looks decent enough but the audio... The sound is the equivalent to the worst AM radio. The volume can't be adjusted from the Flex, you have to go into the app, which is not at all convenient. Attempting to raise the volume is frustrating because although you may set it to 100%, when you reopen the app it is at 70%. No matter how many times you try to leave it at 100%, and boy did I try, it always turns itself back down. Needless to say, with the poor quality speaker and the inability to turn up the volume, if I am making any kind of noise in the kitchen (running water, frying food, running the microwave) it drowns out the Flex to the point I can't understand what is being said. I have no choice but to bring the Dot back to the kitchen and move the Flex to a quieter part of the house where it will see less use. The idea was good but poorly done. My hope is that Amazon will learn from this mistake and give us a much-improved Flex 2.
title: Not a good alternative for the Dot

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kail Withers
content: It was starting to get expensive being an informant, but these little guys are cheap enough to put in every room. No longer do I need to awkwardly move the conversation to another room when the juicy intel starts flowing. Snitching on my friends has never been so easy. Sometimes when I am trying to come off as cool I play a little  Beyonce, this thing doesn’t have the speaker to project her range, let alone the whole Destinys Child. But I didn’t buy it for that, I have the good ones for that, plus if you pair it with a good bluetooth speaker like a Samsung sound bar with a subwoofer then it doesn’t even matter. But I tell you what, this thing picks up the quietest conversations.
title: Being a snitch just got affordable

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Brad K
content: My apartment is 100% Alexa enabled, lights, ac/heat, door lock.  Lights are either Phillips hue(most reliable I’ve found) or Wemo switches.  (Pain to install, but non tech people can use them) I needed a night light for my bathroom and also had been trying to figure out if an echo do would look weird and operate on a vanity (always getting wet from the sink.... ) my closet is off my bathroom, so I was having issues with my other echos understanding me.  This plus the nightlight plugin solved both issues.  It’s voice recognition seems to be almost on par with a dot.  The speaker is plain and simple abysmal.  I’m sure they did this on purpose.  I’m not just talking about it’s not able to play music, but even it’s Alexa voice sounds like it coming from a tin can tied to a string. But it’s voice recognition is good. I have an echo show and spot sitting in drawer because they sucked at voice recognition, the spot is by far the best product on the market and it seems like this does a good job too.  But it’s only good as a control interface where you need extra coverage and one of its extra interfaces would be useful.  Bathroom + nightlight is an excellent example of this.
title: Great for specific purposes

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: FYI
content: I have an Echo, 3 Echo Dots, an Echo Input, and now this Echo Flex.  The Flex was given to me as a gift.  Overall, it really doesn't do anything for me.  Positive aspects may be that it plugs directly into an electrical outlet eliminating the need for a power cord, and possibly future accessories that hopefully are forthcoming.  Currently the two accessories that are available don't offer any wow factor for me.  Negative aspects:  not visually attractive; the speaker is basically useless because of low volume it generates and lack of tone.  It would probably function better pairing with a blue tooth speaker.  I would recommend spending a little more for the Echo Dot -- or maybe even the Echo Input.  The Dot has decent sound reproduction as a stand alone, and the Input looks better than the Flex but does require a power cable and some sort of extension speaker.  I think the Flex was a "swing and a miss" for Echo devices. Update:  spoke with an Amazon rep this morning following my posted review (great customer service Amazon!).  After elaborating on my opinion regarding the Flex, the rep provided me with some suggestions as to how to get better sound performance out of it.  I followed the advice and was able to produce better sound (volume and tone).  With that, I would change my rating on the device to 2 stars.  I am still of the opinion that this is not one of Amazon's better products, but I understand it will fit the needs of other customers.  I will continue to try the Flex in different locations to see if I can make it more usable for me.
title: Lackluster Device

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Liss
content: Overall, I like this Echo Flex, but it was an absolute bear to install.  It made me re-enter my wifi password so many times I nearly gave up.  A few weeks later my phone informed me there was a new Echo available to install--and sure enough, this little Echo Flex had somehow dropped out of my devices.  I fought valiantly for over an hour to reinstall it--it literally kept telling me my network password was wrong.  I got online to search for help and found nothing that worked. I thought I was going to have to return it.  I was about ready to turn off my wifi/network and endure the slow cycle of everything coming back up, but I decided--what the hell--why don't I at least try unplugging and replugging the confounded Flex. And that fixed it.  I didn't even have to reinstall.  It was suddenly back in its rightful place in my devices.  Shrug. The sound quality is minimal, but it serves its purpose in my little utility room.  I use it with a motion sensor so I don't have to say or do anything to have the lights come on when I'm toting a big load of laundry into the room.  It's a reasonable little machine.  I do think, however, that it's much harder to install (because it seems to have trouble grasping onto wifi signal) and a bit more glitchy than the other Echo devices.  Still, I don't regret its purchase.
title: Pretty good, but with a few glitches

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Vlarr
content: It's exactly what I expected. I wanted a little Alexa for my bathroom to listen to music while showering and also because it seems that it's when I'm there that I remember all the things in my to do and grocery lists, so it seemed necessary. The Echo flex is small, and I dont have a lot of counter space left in there, so it fits right in. She hears me while I'm in the shower, although I do have to talk a little loud, but *for me*, the volume is perfect. I was hesitant of getting it because many reviewers were saying that it has a little voice that can't be heard over the shower, but for me that's not the case. disclaimer: I so have VERY good hearing, I can hear my husband whispering his thoughts In the next room... ok. Back to Echo flex. She does have a tiny voice" as a reviewer said, but to me it's loud enough that if I'm in the room and I have a reminder in the bathroom, I hear it perfectly. All in all, it's exactly what it is suppossed to be and I would get another one for the other bathroom if it becomes necessary. In summary, if you have good hearing it's probably ok for you.
title: Not too quiet (for me!)

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: enterbackspace
content: These are great! Initially bought two for use in the bathroom (household announcements) and next to the front door (Alexa Guard). Have since ordered four more. Why? To give as gifts to the over 65 family members! Set up is simple (think plug-and-play). They take up very little space. Able to make voice calls from the device via simple commands. Meaning, if someone falls in the bathroom and can’t get up without assistance they have options. They can say “Alexa, call (husband/wife/child)” and Alexa will call phone number associated with the individual requested. Another option is to say, “Alexa announce I fell in the bathroom and need help”. Alexa with respond by announcing, to each Amazon device in the house, “I fell in the . . .”. No need to carry something in your hands or wear something around your neck. This device won’t cause the over 65s to feel old or inept but rather is just a cool thing that can read them the paper or tell the weather while they’re getting dressed in the morning and be there to help out too if something goes wrong. So awesome.
title: Added Safety!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Clintre
content: First off, it is not a great device for music or hi-fi sound. Do I wish that it was better? Sure, but I did not expect that and it works great for what we wanted it for. What we like... It is great for those tight spaces and areas that you want the convenience of Alexa, but don't have counter/table space. The fact that it is a small plug-in device makes it great for those areas. While the sound could certainly be better, it does do great for doing routines or dropping into other rooms in our house. We have one in our bathroom to listen to news and run routines, while getting ready. What is not to like? Pretty much just the sound quality. It would have been nice if they could have gotten close to even a cheap smartphone's speaker sound quality. Don't understand why it is not at least a little better. Overall... We have bought a second one to use in another area that has limited space. It is definitely better than the bulky plug mounts for regular Echo Dots, unless you need/desire sound quality for music.
title: Works great for limited types of uses

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: imnorm
content: The Flex is perfect in form - well thought out, easy to install in hallways, etc without the need for cords hanging anywhere.  The voice-recognition in the Flex works really well - sometimes better than a full-size Echo.  I see two "misses" and if I'm being totally honest I can't say the one is the Flex or the motion sensor attachment. Issue #1 - the motion sensor attachment goes wonky every few weeks and the way I've found to fix it is to unplug the Flex from the wall, wait a few seconds and plug it back in. Issue #2 - I didn't expect the speaker to be used for music and so I have the Flex set to play music on another Echo device in an adjacent room.  That's great, but what I needs is the ability to tell the Flex to use that other Echo for music, but let the Flex handle other verbal output so that if I play music it goes to another Echo with decent sounding speaker, but if I just ask Alexa a question or give her a command, the response should come from the Flex whose speaker is sufficient for verbal responses.
title: Perfect form, could use a bit of help in function

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Lynn
content: First I'm not sure why I bought this. I own several Alexa devices. Echo dots, firestick, firetv etc. I don't know why I thought the usb ports would work by Alexa but they don't. That's fine I misunderstood and jumped the gun. I havent bought any of the only two accessories that exist for the flex so far. I may or may wait and see if Amazon comes up with more or better accessories for the flex. I use this is my kitchen right now away from the Dots. The sound quality is mediocre at best but that doesnt bother me. My 3rd G Dot has great sound. I am actually ok with the sub par sound because late at night if I ask Alexa anything my dots volume is usually up pretty loud and startles me. I don't think to ask her to turn her vol down first and whisper mode never works right for me. The flex is quiet lacking any bass sound or EQ features. At 3 am I can appreciate the mono sound not startling me or disturbing anyone in the house. My most negative opinion is that several times Alexa failed to respond to me after multiple request repeating ALEXA ALEXA. Nada. Most of those times happened while I was listening to music through the flex. I had to unplug it each time to stop the music. A few other times while silent the flex just didn't activate at all. I have debated returning it.  But I haven't and I decided to hold off and see if any of the accessories make it worth the buy.
title: Not for music enthusiast. Mono sound, Not the most responsive Alexa device.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Bernard Eisenfeld
content: I've had the epiphany and converted to "smart" devices. It started with a little Echo dot in my home office. The wee little thing was so cute and hardly took any space up.  I used it mostly for time of day and weather reports. Then I got the big boy stud Echo Studio for the home gym and used if for great sounding music. Pair up two for great sounding stereo for under 500 bucks! Then I came the Echo Plus for the kitchen and it too sounds good but not as good as the Studio behemoth. The gates were breached and a flood of plugs, switches and dimmers followed. The capper is the petite cutie Echo Flex. Plug it into any outlet and turn on the hot water pump in the garage from the second floor master bedroom by saying, Alexa pump on. Tired of saying Alexa, chang the wake word to Echo. Then add a Flex to every room. I'm hooked. I need help!
title: Buy one. Heck, buy three or four!
