title: Horrible product. Do not recommend

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Suzannah
content: I have tons of Alexa devices, this is by far my least favorite. It seems I have to reconnect the device every other week and I’ve had it less than a year. I’ve only had to do that once to my Echo Show in the two years I’ve had it. I bought the Flex for my laundry room so I can continue to hear my audiobook as I do my chores moving from room to room while the book plays on the everywhere group. This DARN hunk of plastic is always suddenly disconnected from the group and from my network every other week while all my other devices continue working perfectly fine. I didn’t even mind the tinny/weak speaker it has because I listen to books mostly but without a connection it just sucks up my electricity until I can stop what I’m doing and reset/reconnect everything. This product is a dud in my opinion. Oh, and my laundry room is near my router and not on the other side of my house. I have Alexa devices much further away that work fine.
title: I’m about to chuck this piece of plastic

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: RoboTech
content: First off, the product description SPECIFICALLY STATES that it is not made for music. It is NOT a replacement for an Echo Dot as far as sound quality goes. I am not going to due the product a disservice by giving it a 1-star rating for that reason alone, like other have. I also own several Dot's attached to wall mounts. They are in areas that are clean and dust free, whereas the Flex can be hooked up in a dusty garage or shed without worrying about the speaker cloth getting torn, dirty or moldy. The Flex can be just wiped off with a damp cloth. Even with the Dots on sale, the total cost with a good wall mount is at least $35. The Flex is replacing my Echo Inputs and a couple of my Dots. No cords or mounting worries and about the same price as the Input. I bought the Flex to use in the garage connected to a stereo system and also in a hallway with the night light plug-in. The Flex is the perfect solution and a lot cheaper than a Dot w/wall mount configuration in tight spots where you are not going to use the internal speaker anyhow. Plus, the added benefit of a USB port on the bottom to charge your phone, plug in a night light, or to power a set of USB speakers. As for the microphones, I am not sure why people are reporting that the microphones don't work well. All (3) of my Flex pick up my voice just fine from across the room. Just because the Flex has only 2 microphones, doesn't mean as much as you'd think. The DOT is usually mounted flat on a table and needs all 6 mics to pick up your voice from all angles. The FLEX on the other hand, is plugged into a wall and only has to pick up your voice from a much narrower angle. I have found that the microphones on the DOT can get "confused" when mounted vertically on the wall. The blue ring on the Dot that lights up when activated, has a brighter spot on the ring that corresponds with the direction of your voice. Sometimes you will see the ring on the Dot "spinning" as it picks up your voice bouncing all over the place. The 2 mics on the Flex are better suited for wall mounting. More is not always better. Realistically, nothing is perfect and sure, they could have put a bigger speaker in it. A larger speaker most certainly would have increased the price and made it physically larger. People would then be complaining about that. For me, I am glad is has a speaker for audible Alexa responses at least. In summary, the Flex is not perfect, but for specific purposes and for the price it can't be beat as long as you are not expecting to use it for music (or in a noisy environment) using the built in speaker.
title: Perfect solution for using in a tight space connected to another speaker system.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: En Yu
content: I only started using devices like echo dot or Alexa recently. It started 2018 Black Friday echo sale I believe. Only started using it properly spring 2019. I began to realize how helpful it can be. Alarms, lists, music, orders, time, weather, news, topic look up, definitions & so much more. Then I discovered the smart bulbs which are really helpful. I don't have to stumble around to turn on my lamp anymore. Then I discovered the smart plugs which I mostly use for starting kitchen appliances. When I got an email about this being on a 50% off sale, I took the leap to get another area in my home Alexa friendly. I knew that the speaker would not be very loud after reading the introduction but we have a sound bar that can be linked to it when we need it to be louder. Setting it up was easy peasy with the Alexa App. I've also learnt how to 'intercom' between Echos so another discovery! I also love that its plug in so no wires & we save table/counter space. All in all, an ultra affordable voice assist device to add to your home!
title: Easy Peasy to Setup

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Bernard Eisenfeld
content: I've had the epiphany and converted to "smart" devices. It started with a little Echo dot in my home office. The wee little thing was so cute and hardly took any space up.  I used it mostly for time of day and weather reports. Then I got the big boy stud Echo Studio for the home gym and used if for great sounding music. Pair up two for great sounding stereo for under 500 bucks! Then I came the Echo Plus for the kitchen and it too sounds good but not as good as the Studio behemoth. The gates were breached and a flood of plugs, switches and dimmers followed. The capper is the petite cutie Echo Flex. Plug it into any outlet and turn on the hot water pump in the garage from the second floor master bedroom by saying, Alexa pump on. Tired of saying Alexa, chang the wake word to Echo. Then add a Flex to every room. I'm hooked. I need help!
title: Buy one. Heck, buy three or four!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Cynthiatxrn
content: This is a great addon to ur existing Alexa Smart home. It is not made to stream music, the sound quality is not great, but this is not made to be a music speaker, it’s made to give u Alexa access in other parts of ur home. I love it! I am now able to tell Alexa to turn on/off the lights & Alexa guard as I am leaving & entering my home downstairs without having to buy another Alexa echo for an area of the house we don’t use much. I put it by the garage door. No need for playing music there, I just want to be able to tell Alexa I’m home or I’m leaving so she can turn off & on the lights for me. Now I don’t have to go up the stairs in the dark until I get to my main Alexa port in the Living room to turn the lights on. I also bought the nightlight addon which lights up the hallway downstairs for me. The light addon can change to any color you want. The only downside... you can only use one addon. I also bought the motion sensor addon, but I had to choose between the nightlite or the morion sensor. I chose the nightlight. I wish I could have used both the nightlite AND the motion detector. Other than that, it does what is was made for... to give u Alexa voice command capabilities in an area of the house that you do not have an Alexa echo or other main Alexa device.
title: Great addon to an Alexa Smarthome setup! Control Alexa anywhere in ur home!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: T. Edel
content: Depends on how they're used.  I bought 4.  Two for my father-in-law's house to add on motion detectors.  They work great for that.  The other two were for my wife (in the laundry room) and my son so they could listen to music on demand.  They now hate me for doing that.  I have Alexa built into an Ecobee thermostat and my wife plays music through that all the time.  It doesn't sound as good as a 2nd gen Echo Dot, but good enough for her ears.  I figured the Flex couldn't be much worse than that.  I was wrong.  They don't use them often enough for Bluetooth.  I use an aux cable to hook my son's up to his mini hi-fi, but it doesn't push enough power even for that.  Very weak sounding.  And he looses the convenience of just asking for music, he would have to turn the stereo on to hear it.  Worse yet, we paid the same for them that we just paid for th 3rd Gen Dot on Prime Day!  These will have to be re-purposed for something, just don't know what yet...  But they work great for motion detection!!  (with the add-on).
title: Somewhat disappointed

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kaleem
content: This is a basic device for voice recognition for Alexa. The sound quality isn't great and the voice recognition (which works pretty well) is not as sensitive like the dot and echo. This was expected of course being the lower end of the set. It however, works pretty well. I hooked up a pair of old speakers to the flex which improves the sound quality, but mostly use it for controlling my lights and devices around the house as well as keeping notes. Its a good purchase if you want to use it for just voice control, rather than playing music. (you can still hook up your speakers if needed)
title: Worth for its purpose

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: MJ
content: The need for a product in the echo line of this type has been long needed. The current versions I received and the lack of basic functionality clearly shows that any current buyers are unwilling beta testers. I do believe when the programming is finally completed an the advertise functionality Does function this will be a very useful product. Will you tell the function of an echo device to be placed in utility room, laundry rooms, bathrooms, hallways, stairs and dozens of other locations it will serve us extremely well and be extremely dependable and survive environments the normal echo dot or echo would not survive in is it biggest plus. So often and all meeting at your house smart switches require the rewiring of the house and to have a product with a motion Detector that can turn on and turn off lights or other electrical equipment that you would like to turn on or off Automatically when you enter Area will be extremely helpful and even life-saving and not requiring special wiring or anything new the B installed inside but plugging it into an outlet. I look very forward to when Amazon Alexa support team completes the basic programming that should have been done before the release and this is a fully functioning product. And also will be of great use to the handicapped and those with mobility issues so it will eventually be one of the best products Amazon Alexa has made in the Echo line.
title: Great product, But Beware the programming is still Not completed

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Craig M. Reed
content: While yes it is functional with controlling other lights and giving you the weather, time, etc. I am kinda disappointed in this device. I know I only paid $25 for it but the volume level is so horrible it almost renders it useless in my opinion. If there are no other sounds in the room, and you listen VERY carefully you’ll be able to hear it. Not made for music or calls that’s for sure.
title: Somewhat useful

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Gabriel
content: After reading the reviews on this little Alexa Flex Device I wasn't sure what to expect?  I must say that this Ecco Flex is much better than some of the reviewers give it credit for.  It is a small device and for the size of it, I am very pleased with its attributes.  The speaker is tiny so it sounds more like the old fashioned transistor radio without the static, but the sound is bold enough to hear throughout the large room that I have it in.  So I am impressed with that.  I added the night light and that is an excellent feature to have in a bedroom.  The Alexa app added the flex on immediately to my devices and it gives you the ability to fine-tune the many settings that the flex is capable of as well as the night light that I added as an accessory.  I want to add that Music sounds very good but do remember that it is heard from a very small speaker that is not related to a Boze system. But for the size and the money, I am very pleased with the flex.
title: Much better than Reviews

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: J.
content: No one expect any great soumd quality, in my personal view. The device is simply and specifically advertised as a mobile extension of Alexa. Now that that statement has been made for clarity towards my review, I find that using this where I have pluged the device in at, my bathroom, reveals an issue where when on the side of the bathroom opposite of the device, the Echo Flex is unable to pick up my commands/inquiries when speaking I  an otherwise, not loud but tone able to be picked up anyone else in theroom on the side that the Echo Flex is installed/plugged in at as well as people standing outside of the bathroom could also pick up and discern what I am saying. The Echo Flex is installed/plugged into an outlet just next to the bathroom entrance. I note this to show that while the Echo Flex was unable to pick up my voice, people in the room with me, as well as people outside of the bathroom. On the other side of the door where Alexa Echo Flex is installed/plugged in at, were in fact able to pick up my voice as well as able to understand what I was saying to the Amazon Echo Flex. As a result of the voice detection limitation, I have ordered Amazon's white Echo input as to replace the Flex and intend to purchase bluetooth enabled outdoor speaker for mount in the the bathroom and to be linked/connected to the Amazon Echo Input that was purchased to replace the Echo Flex.
title: Certainly is an extension of the Alexa AI, with voice pick up limitations in my experience.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Medtec M.
content: I see a number of reviews where the reviewer described the sound quality as bad.  If you were planning to play music out of the internal speaker you will be disappointed BUT (and it's a big Serena Williams BUT') you shouldn't be using the internal speaker for that.  Everyone forgets to mention that it has a stereo output port.  You need to use it.  Plug that into your home stereo or high quality computer speaker.  It is then that you will have sound quality that far exceeds any stand-alone smart speaker you can find at ten times the price.  Additionally, that little internal speaker actually articulates better than the larger echos because it doesn't even try to reproduce the low frequencies, so for reproducing voices like news, audio books, Alexa-read Kindle books and phone calls it also functions better. You get all of this for only $25 and since I got it mine on sale for $10, the value I have received is tremendous. You may be asking yourselves "If it's so great then why didn't you give it five stars?"  This is because I don't give out five stars.  I like to leave some headroom for when I'm absolutely blown away by a product and, so far, with my 58 years into this life, I haven' t felt like that about anything. My recommendation:  Buy it and love it for years.  You won't regret it.  I bet you had more buyer's remorse over that high school sweetheart you married just a few short years ago.  You know, that "I'll love you until the end of time" girl.  Yeah right.  You're ready to hit the escape hatch on that one, aren't ya?
title: The sound quality is excellent and here's why...

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Pussy Galore
content: If it didn't come with the free Lfyt Wifi light bulb, I would have return it since I could get 2 for better price on other side. Seriously, other site have a lower price on the device on amazon itself! It works well enough, sound it's spectacular. Mic was responsive. I initially was confuse if it have a mic in it as it have an input for mic/speak.Yes, it does. I was not able to find similar brand light bulb with  RGB. I have bought 2 more for living room but of other brand. I realize each would need their app to start and to control the more details function. Being my tablet does not have a lot of memory, I can be an issue. The bulb app integrated with Alexa well, but it has been twice that the bulb disconnected from Alexa and have to relink. Same as other RGB brand. 1st time it occur, it was all off them off the wifi and have to reset. Alexa app itself have nice function, like add stuff to your shopping list, set alarm and to radio and certain music subscription. My only concern is that how much privacy and security it has. Unless I "turn off" the mic. Another con is that it does not have a wire but plug directly into the wall outlet like the other echo. I use a 3 splitter on the wall, so it allows me one more item to okay in.
title: Decent. $10 with free wifi light bulb made it acceptable

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: B
content: Love these! I purchased them for the office and places that don't have a convenient place to set an Echo Dot, such as the garage. It is far more sensitive than my Echo Dots or Echo Show. It picks up the wake word from 50 ft which is amazing since I sometimes have to yell at my Echo Show from just 10 ft. The sound is a little quiet and scratchy when compared with other Echo devices. Not exactly ideal for playing music but does well enough it clear and intelligible. You can still retain access to the upper plug when this is plugged in. Very easy to setup and only takes a few minutes once you have the app. I highly recommend these. They would be great for people that are new to the smart home things. They are cheap, effective and allow you to try it out without breaking the bank. They make it easy to have Alexa in every room. I use it frequently to announce when dinner is ready or to drop in on my kids when I'm not home.
title: Must Have for your Smart Home

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: WoodlandKathy
content: I love the size. It set up automatically. I didn't have to do a thing except plug it in. I have 3 Echo Dots [3rd Gen]. And multiple smart plugs. I added a night light to the Flex & love that it's dimmable for the bathroom. I care little that the speaker is not high quality. I'm only using it to listen to the news & check the weather. Maybe set a timer, add to my lists or ask Alexa something important while I'm brushing my teeth or doing laundry which is also in the bathroom. Very very happy with this new Echo. P.S. if after a time using it I want a better speaker I'll pair a Bluetooth with it.
title: Perfect for the bathroom

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: M. Anderson
content: I was tired of screaming, "Alexa, turn off the bedroom lights. DAMMIT! ALEXA. TURN. OFF. THE. BEDROOM. LIGHTS," to our living room Echo device when my husband was staying up watching TV and I was headed to bed. Sometimes I wondered if my neighbors could hear me. Most of the time my voice wouldn't get recognized and I'd have to mute the TV or scream into the Echo an inch away from it for it to hear me. What was the point? I didn't want to buy an entirely new Echo just for the bedroom in our small one bedroom apartment. I'm glad they came up with this. Now I can quietly go into the bedroom while the TV is on and gently ask Alexa to do things. The default audio from the device is definitely not the best quality (our main Echo is hooked up to our speaker system) but it's nice enough. I like the lights on the device that mirror the regular Echo, so I know what's going on with it. I had a little trouble setting it up because I guess our internet isn't the best, but eventually got it synced. Thank you for preventing me from being that one neighbor you can hear yelling at their Echo.
title: Great add-on. Stop yelling at Alexa!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Seth I Levine
content: This is a pretty OK Echo device. It certainly has its good points! When used with the motion sensor (which is what I'm doing), it really could only work in a hallway type of situation. The problem, as I see it, is that it needs to be plugged directly into an outlet, and, in my house anyway, most of the outlets in rooms where I might want this to work, are below knee level and behind furniture - except in the hallway. I suppose the nightlight option would work well in the hallway situation, too, but it's too bad you can't have both the nightlight AND motion sensor. The Alexa functionality of this device is just like all other Alexa devices. It can hear from all around a room and answer questions or follow commands. The speaker is definitely not worthy of playing music with much fidelity. Right now, I'm using it in my garage to control an adjacent smart switch to turn the garage lights on in reaction to the motion sensor. That seems like a perfect fit for this combination of devices. I'm not really sure how else one might use this, because most outlets in most homes in the US are not accessible in a way that would work with this thing. If I had a very specific use case where I knew this would work, I'd buy it again. Otherwise, I wish there was a motion sensor option from Amazon that didn't require being plugged directly into a wall outlet.
title: It's an odd combination of brilliant and dumb

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Matt Seegers
content: I wanted to try out the Flex right when Amazon announced the new product but only recently had a chance to purchase them. My intended use-case was for the two bathrooms in my apartment.  My wife and I almost exclusively listen to NPR while we're in the bathroom getting ready for the day and have been resorting to using one of our phones to play it.  This works pretty well but obviously can lead to some risks/issues:  the phones' speakers are *almost* loud enough to hear while in the shower.  If you place the phone in a sink it boosts the volume just enough.  As one may expect, this has resulted in many close calls with water. Initial Setup: Fantastically easy, just like any Amazon Echo device Physical Size: just small enough that it shouldn't block both outlets in a dual outlet... outlet. Experience:  Speech recognition just as good as any Echo device, but I have only used them in bathrooms, which is likely easier for the mic(s) to pick up.  Loading apps (like NPR) or pairing using bluetooth is just like any other Echo device (ie fast and relatively painless).  Audio sounds good--but, as is essentially mentioned in product description, is not designed for rich (ie music) audio and does not get very loud.  I would rate the loudness to be lower than an iPhone 7 or later. Takeaway: This is a great device to integrate voice control in a small/medium room.  However, if you want to use it for audio and there is any ambient noise in the room I would recommend either using external speakers (plugged in to the audio-out and/or USB port) or external bluetooth speakers.  If your main goal was to get audio into a room it may be more cost effective to find an all-in-one solution that can support voice control and also has solid speakers.  For me, I am hoping that there will be more Flex accessories that could potentially address this issue (ie a Flex Speaker that plugs into the USB port and fits the same form factor).
title: Great for adding voice control to any small/med room with low ambient noise

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Janet Cullen
content: I bought this Echo Flex for my bedroom. I have smart bulbs in my room. So I needed a device to turn them on & off. Plus I also wanted the extra features like asking Alexa what time it is, the weather, playing my Amazon Music while I'm getting ready. This Echo Flex really is helpful. Although at times it does not respond. Especially when I'm standing in total darkness asking it to turn on the light.....and nothing happens. Sometimes I have to ask many times. I do have 1 reg bulb. To get to it in the total darkness could cause injury to myself. LOL So I stand there asking Alexa numerous times in different ways to turn on the lights. My Echo Flex seems to be quirky. I have it in a clear spot so I know it can hear me. The wifi router is in the next room so I know there isnt an issue with connection. I have been told I speak to loud so I know it is not my voice. In the end The Echo Flex is worth it for my needs.
title: Good for my needs

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Rae Danielle
content: I expected these to suck based off other reviews but honestly they don’t.. I am not sure why everyone complains about the sound, it sounds fine to me. We have just about every echo device there is. The flex we have in our kids bedrooms and our basement  so they can listen to music. I would have gotten a dot like we have in the dining room but the flex are cheaper and I like that there isn’t a cord. The sound quality might not be as great as the other echo devices but honestly I don’t notice much of a difference.. for listening to music and everything else honestly I don’t see a problem. I mean we aren’t having a party or anything so the music isn’t getting blasted on these, these are just for casual listening while in bedrooms or in the basement game room. When they are on in the bedrooms I can hear them all over the house unless they close their door or I ask them to turn them down. Overall I’m pleased with these. They’re perfect for what we wanted and they honestly exceeded my expectations based off other reviews.
title: Better than expected

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: DLM
content: In a time when it's usually "go big or go home", sometimes smaller is better.  Such is the case with the Echo Flex.  I have 2 Dots, and a fairly sprawled out house, with a basement.  I wanted a simple way to keep the family connected, and had already found out how handy (and fun) the Dots were, so I added 2 Flex. The whole set up works like a charm and is easy to use.  I can now "drop in" on someone in the basement while I'm in the living room, or (as the ad says) call everyone to dinner, no matter where they are just by asking Echo to do so.  I've had a ball programming each to say certain things at certain times (the Flex at the back door has the job of reminding hubby at 6 am to make sure he has everything before he leaves for work). The Flex are small enough to not take up a lot of room. As a bonus, for these two I also purchased the night lights to go along with them, so they pull double duty.  Quite simply, we love them!
title: Handy!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Brian S. Dart
content: This is a nifty little device. Is it for quality music???? No Is it fancy looking??? No But what it is, is a perfect little device for my garage or maybe a basement to control lights or smart devices. I out it in my garage for security. You get out of the car and turn on the lights in the house. Or turn them off because I am notorious for forgetting to do that before I leave. I got it on sale so for the price it is great. Also one worry I had was the operating temperature. It says it is rated down to 32 degrees. Well I haven't had it long and the temperature in my garage has been down near single digits and so far so good!  I figured for the price it was worth trying to see if it survived. If you are looking for sound quality buy an external speaker for it or buy one of the other items with the better speaker. But for control of your smart devices this little thing has been great!
title: Excellent for a inexpensive way to control your smart home.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: S from C
content: We have Echo Dots in almost every room in the house and love them. We use them mostly to play the radio, podcasts, sleep sounds and as an intercom system We didn't have one in the kitchen because we didn't have the space for it and we already have a radio in there. We added the Echo Flex  because it doesn't take up any counter space and we wanted to have an intercom because the kitchen is on the opposite end of the house from the living room and we end up doing a lot of shouting back and forth. Unfortunately, the sound quality is so poor that you usually can't understand what the other person is saying - especially when there is background noise in the kitchen. You can hear that the other person is saying something, but can't understand what it is.  We are now trying to figure out where we can put a Dot in the kitchen. I would only recommend this to use as an intercom in a small, quiet room. You will NOT want to listen to music, news, white noise or anything else on an Echo Flex!
title: Very Poor Sound Quality

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: An Egg
content: We bought a pair of these after having a baby so that my husband could talk to me in the nursery from anywhere in the house. We specifically added them to the kitchen and nursery. Unfortunately the flex doesn't handle extraneous noise well at all. Half the time it doesn't hear me at all, and when it does it often doesn't hear correctly. In the kitchen, it doesn't have enough volume to be heard over any cooking or clanking, and in the nursery we have to put it at volume 10 for white noise to be loud enough. About the only thing it has been reliably good for is setting timers. Not worth the money paid for it.
title: It can't hear me and I can't hear it

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: J. O'Malley
content: This little gadget is pretty awesome, actually. First of all, it doesn't take up a whole lot of room. It has Bluetooth, so if the speaker sounds tinny (and it does a little bit, but the sound quality isn't horrible) it can connect to a speaker and boom-boom just like the bigger Echo products. The microphones in this unit are very responsive so I don't feel the need to shout at the Echo Flex (like I need to with my first-gen 2014 Amazon Echo sometimes). It has everything you love about the Echo, plus some extra tricks - it has a USB port in the bottom so you can charge your phone or attach one of the THIRDREALITY dongles they have available, such as a night light or a motion sensor. I keep it in my bathroom so I can listen to my morning Flash Briefing while I get ready for work, and I charge up my phone for the day at the same time. It's a little blocky and I have to unplug it to use my blow-dryer because it takes up so much room on the electrical outlet on the wall. It would also be better if it came in black, but all in all, this is a solid product.
title: Alexa Lite! Vry very handy

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: PattyT
content: I went a little crazy and bought an Echo Show 8 and 5 as well as this Flex. I already had a Dot. I bought this little Flex originally for my bedroom to control the light and also to interact with but the sound quality isn't great and I have hearing loss without my cochlear implant on so I moved it to the bathroom. It works great in there. I often have it play music or the latest news or weather when I am doing my hair and make up, cleaning the bathroom, or even taking a bath and, while it doesn't sound nearly as good as the Echo Shows, it's about on par with my Dot. If I can understand it with my funky ears, it can't be terrible! It's very responsive. Actually more responsive than the Shows and gets what I am saying right almost all the time. Sure, the sound could be better but the speaker is tiny and the price is low. I think it works fine but wouldn't want it as my main Echo device.
title: Sound isn't great but this is a good little add on for small spaces.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: TOm
content: I wanted to like this thing so badly, because it is theoretically a great idea.  A socket mounted, $25 echo that fits well into a bathroom or kitchen, paired with a bluetooth speaker is amazing, and hey, when the thing actually responds to your voice, it is amazing. However, even when there is no sound whatsoever, I sometimes have to literally scream at the thing to wake it, and a good 1/10 times it doesn't understand me.  I will try to talk to it but my echo plus on the other side of the apartment will respond because of how terrible the mics on the flex are.  I have even resorted to giving them different names (which I hate, and shouldn't have to do) but even then, I can be standing in the same exact position directly in front of the flex (which sits at about chest height in my kitchen) and it will sometimes wake, but often just sit there like a useless piece of plastic and circuitry. I am tempted to return this and replace it with an echo, but I'm already beyond the return window, which is frustratingly just long enough to really see these issues.  0/10, would never buy again or recommend unless they double the number of mics or make them more sensitive.
title: Mics are Horrible and Deaf

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: MartysReads
content: I own quite a few echo dots.  I use them in all kinds of ways and they have improved my quality of life (I am so not kidding!) When I saw a sale on this new Echo Flex Plug-in, I jumped at the deal.  And let me say, I am no sound purist, I don't know a subwoofer from a .... well, anything.  I think my dots have better sound quality than my old stereo, and that is  really not something I should admit.  I admit it in order to say: even for me, someone whose bargain smart TV doesn't have a soundbar, etc, the tinny sound quality of Alexa's voice on this device was distracting and well,  distressingly bad.  I mean, I cringed... and prepared  to return it.  My husband decided he didn't mind, so this went in his own study where I won't hear it as he asks for the days sports updates when he returns from work.  I can't bear to listen to it.  I've had long distance calls to foreign countries in the 80s sound better than this. Alexa makes my world work better, I love having her all around my house for music, for making hands free phone calls, etc. (This alone is why I think crappy tinny sound is not ok.... I don't think anyone would understand me over this plug-in if I tried.) If you have ears that work, I suggest you just wait for a sale on the echo dot.  (Don't pay more than $22 if you are thrifty.)
title: Tiny sound incredibly distracting, way beyond "not optimized for music playback"

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Paul Lucas
content: This is Amazing! I love that Amazon placed a device in a package that is easy to plug right into an outlet without having to worry about finding a place to set it. It’s a nice slim form factor and I have this one placed in my laundry room so I can easily drop in on my wife while she folds clothes. That one of the rooms I didn’t have a device nearby.
title: Slim form factor and easy to place

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: iFoxy
content: If you want a taste of what Amazon products can do, this is a easy and cheap way to get into it without investing fully on a Echo Show. While it is not as loud as my Echo show, I love having it in those places like the bathroom and bedroom. I can still have access to music and also tell it to add something to my shopping list which is super helpful for me since I can forget on the way to the living room. I would say on of the main benefits of having one of the Echo Show products is if you need to remove or edit something, its easy cause you can ask it show you your list and then you can touch the items to edit or swipe the item off your list. Also you can ask it to remove an item with audio. Also the Echo show lets you watch movies and the sound is awesome. I recommend all the Amazon Alexa products! So many things I love to do with it to be honest. I would totally get another one if I could. Its just that good. When I move out and get my own house, I'm going to buy more. :)
title: While its no Echo show....it is a great starter speaker.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Impetigo
content: I really love this device except that the response is slow.  I love the simple, Apple-like design.  I love the utility of having a small Echo device that plugs directly in the wall in rooms (e.g. bathroom) where you don't want a full sized Echo (and I am not a fan of the small Echos, the Echo Dot) or it's not practical (or too costly).  The speaker quality is completely fine for what it is.  I love being able to make announcements from any room, to any room. But what I don't love is that there is often a delay with the responsiveness, especially the farther you are from your wifi source (which makes sense since the voice commands are sent to the Amazon data centers that process the commands, like Siri on Apple), that is not an issue with my full sized Echos.  Still, the utility is great so I still like them, just hope they will work on the responsiveness.
title: Awesome!! Except poor responsiveness at times.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Tex75
content: I'm a big fan of the Echo Dot but I don't like looking at the untidy cord. When I saw this for pre-order I thought it would work great in the kitchen to replace the Dot. Set-up was simple and it looks decent enough but the audio... The sound is the equivalent to the worst AM radio. The volume can't be adjusted from the Flex, you have to go into the app, which is not at all convenient. Attempting to raise the volume is frustrating because although you may set it to 100%, when you reopen the app it is at 70%. No matter how many times you try to leave it at 100%, and boy did I try, it always turns itself back down. Needless to say, with the poor quality speaker and the inability to turn up the volume, if I am making any kind of noise in the kitchen (running water, frying food, running the microwave) it drowns out the Flex to the point I can't understand what is being said. I have no choice but to bring the Dot back to the kitchen and move the Flex to a quieter part of the house where it will see less use. The idea was good but poorly done. My hope is that Amazon will learn from this mistake and give us a much-improved Flex 2.
title: Not a good alternative for the Dot

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kail Withers
content: It was starting to get expensive being an informant, but these little guys are cheap enough to put in every room. No longer do I need to awkwardly move the conversation to another room when the juicy intel starts flowing. Snitching on my friends has never been so easy. Sometimes when I am trying to come off as cool I play a little  Beyonce, this thing doesn’t have the speaker to project her range, let alone the whole Destinys Child. But I didn’t buy it for that, I have the good ones for that, plus if you pair it with a good bluetooth speaker like a Samsung sound bar with a subwoofer then it doesn’t even matter. But I tell you what, this thing picks up the quietest conversations.
title: Being a snitch just got affordable

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Brad K
content: My apartment is 100% Alexa enabled, lights, ac/heat, door lock.  Lights are either Phillips hue(most reliable I’ve found) or Wemo switches.  (Pain to install, but non tech people can use them) I needed a night light for my bathroom and also had been trying to figure out if an echo do would look weird and operate on a vanity (always getting wet from the sink.... ) my closet is off my bathroom, so I was having issues with my other echos understanding me.  This plus the nightlight plugin solved both issues.  It’s voice recognition seems to be almost on par with a dot.  The speaker is plain and simple abysmal.  I’m sure they did this on purpose.  I’m not just talking about it’s not able to play music, but even it’s Alexa voice sounds like it coming from a tin can tied to a string. But it’s voice recognition is good. I have an echo show and spot sitting in drawer because they sucked at voice recognition, the spot is by far the best product on the market and it seems like this does a good job too.  But it’s only good as a control interface where you need extra coverage and one of its extra interfaces would be useful.  Bathroom + nightlight is an excellent example of this.
title: Great for specific purposes

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: FYI
content: I have an Echo, 3 Echo Dots, an Echo Input, and now this Echo Flex.  The Flex was given to me as a gift.  Overall, it really doesn't do anything for me.  Positive aspects may be that it plugs directly into an electrical outlet eliminating the need for a power cord, and possibly future accessories that hopefully are forthcoming.  Currently the two accessories that are available don't offer any wow factor for me.  Negative aspects:  not visually attractive; the speaker is basically useless because of low volume it generates and lack of tone.  It would probably function better pairing with a blue tooth speaker.  I would recommend spending a little more for the Echo Dot -- or maybe even the Echo Input.  The Dot has decent sound reproduction as a stand alone, and the Input looks better than the Flex but does require a power cable and some sort of extension speaker.  I think the Flex was a "swing and a miss" for Echo devices. Update:  spoke with an Amazon rep this morning following my posted review (great customer service Amazon!).  After elaborating on my opinion regarding the Flex, the rep provided me with some suggestions as to how to get better sound performance out of it.  I followed the advice and was able to produce better sound (volume and tone).  With that, I would change my rating on the device to 2 stars.  I am still of the opinion that this is not one of Amazon's better products, but I understand it will fit the needs of other customers.  I will continue to try the Flex in different locations to see if I can make it more usable for me.
title: Lackluster Device

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Liss
content: Overall, I like this Echo Flex, but it was an absolute bear to install.  It made me re-enter my wifi password so many times I nearly gave up.  A few weeks later my phone informed me there was a new Echo available to install--and sure enough, this little Echo Flex had somehow dropped out of my devices.  I fought valiantly for over an hour to reinstall it--it literally kept telling me my network password was wrong.  I got online to search for help and found nothing that worked. I thought I was going to have to return it.  I was about ready to turn off my wifi/network and endure the slow cycle of everything coming back up, but I decided--what the hell--why don't I at least try unplugging and replugging the confounded Flex. And that fixed it.  I didn't even have to reinstall.  It was suddenly back in its rightful place in my devices.  Shrug. The sound quality is minimal, but it serves its purpose in my little utility room.  I use it with a motion sensor so I don't have to say or do anything to have the lights come on when I'm toting a big load of laundry into the room.  It's a reasonable little machine.  I do think, however, that it's much harder to install (because it seems to have trouble grasping onto wifi signal) and a bit more glitchy than the other Echo devices.  Still, I don't regret its purchase.
title: Pretty good, but with a few glitches

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Vlarr
content: It's exactly what I expected. I wanted a little Alexa for my bathroom to listen to music while showering and also because it seems that it's when I'm there that I remember all the things in my to do and grocery lists, so it seemed necessary. The Echo flex is small, and I dont have a lot of counter space left in there, so it fits right in. She hears me while I'm in the shower, although I do have to talk a little loud, but *for me*, the volume is perfect. I was hesitant of getting it because many reviewers were saying that it has a little voice that can't be heard over the shower, but for me that's not the case. disclaimer: I so have VERY good hearing, I can hear my husband whispering his thoughts In the next room... ok. Back to Echo flex. She does have a tiny voice" as a reviewer said, but to me it's loud enough that if I'm in the room and I have a reminder in the bathroom, I hear it perfectly. All in all, it's exactly what it is suppossed to be and I would get another one for the other bathroom if it becomes necessary. In summary, if you have good hearing it's probably ok for you.
title: Not too quiet (for me!)

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: enterbackspace
content: These are great! Initially bought two for use in the bathroom (household announcements) and next to the front door (Alexa Guard). Have since ordered four more. Why? To give as gifts to the over 65 family members! Set up is simple (think plug-and-play). They take up very little space. Able to make voice calls from the device via simple commands. Meaning, if someone falls in the bathroom and can’t get up without assistance they have options. They can say “Alexa, call (husband/wife/child)” and Alexa will call phone number associated with the individual requested. Another option is to say, “Alexa announce I fell in the bathroom and need help”. Alexa with respond by announcing, to each Amazon device in the house, “I fell in the . . .”. No need to carry something in your hands or wear something around your neck. This device won’t cause the over 65s to feel old or inept but rather is just a cool thing that can read them the paper or tell the weather while they’re getting dressed in the morning and be there to help out too if something goes wrong. So awesome.
title: Added Safety!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Clintre
content: First off, it is not a great device for music or hi-fi sound. Do I wish that it was better? Sure, but I did not expect that and it works great for what we wanted it for. What we like... It is great for those tight spaces and areas that you want the convenience of Alexa, but don't have counter/table space. The fact that it is a small plug-in device makes it great for those areas. While the sound could certainly be better, it does do great for doing routines or dropping into other rooms in our house. We have one in our bathroom to listen to news and run routines, while getting ready. What is not to like? Pretty much just the sound quality. It would have been nice if they could have gotten close to even a cheap smartphone's speaker sound quality. Don't understand why it is not at least a little better. Overall... We have bought a second one to use in another area that has limited space. It is definitely better than the bulky plug mounts for regular Echo Dots, unless you need/desire sound quality for music.
title: Works great for limited types of uses

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: imnorm
content: The Flex is perfect in form - well thought out, easy to install in hallways, etc without the need for cords hanging anywhere.  The voice-recognition in the Flex works really well - sometimes better than a full-size Echo.  I see two "misses" and if I'm being totally honest I can't say the one is the Flex or the motion sensor attachment. Issue #1 - the motion sensor attachment goes wonky every few weeks and the way I've found to fix it is to unplug the Flex from the wall, wait a few seconds and plug it back in. Issue #2 - I didn't expect the speaker to be used for music and so I have the Flex set to play music on another Echo device in an adjacent room.  That's great, but what I needs is the ability to tell the Flex to use that other Echo for music, but let the Flex handle other verbal output so that if I play music it goes to another Echo with decent sounding speaker, but if I just ask Alexa a question or give her a command, the response should come from the Flex whose speaker is sufficient for verbal responses.
title: Perfect form, could use a bit of help in function

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: L. M Young
content: Our laundry room is downstairs and often I cannot hear the bell go off when the washer or the dryer is finished. We had a cheap baby monitor in the laundry room and the receiver in the living room and monitored the laundry that way, but it was fifteen years old and static-y. Audio-only baby monitors in stores had terrible ratings and were about 30 dollars. For reasons too long to enumerate, we bought an Echo Show 5, so we moved the previously-used Echo Dot in the laundry room and used it for drop-ins; the sound was so much better. But I wanted the Dot for use in another room and using it just as a "baby monitor" seemed silly. Then I saw this little Flex on sale! Since I won't be playing music on it, there's no need for optimum sound out of the tiny speakers, and it's still useful for dropping in, asking the time or the temperature, etc. This is a great alternative to the Dot if you're not concerned with sound fidelity; talked to my husband on it via drop in and he says the sound coming via the Flex is pretty good!
title: Nifty If You Don't Mind Sound Quality

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Asta
content: I was excited when I saw this item released as having additional wires around is generally annoying; and one of my devices is in our kitchen which made it perfect height. I did read that the device was not "music quality" sound and thought that was fine as all I needed it for was mainly alarms and daily functioning, unfortunately that description was an understatement. The sound quality was awful. At volume 10 (max volume) the sound was maybe comparable to volume 3 of regular alexa devices, on top of that it was very grainy sounding. Alexa had a hard time hearing us, even though she is supposed to have long range listening. I had another device in my room next to my bed, maybe four feet from the head of the bed and she wouldn't recognize when I spoke to her from that distance. I was able to charge my phone from the USB port on the bottom but that was about the only good function. Overall the idea was great, making a more compact alexa device and having the motion light attachments etc, but after a month of testing it out it wasn't worth it and we upgraded to 3rd gen Dots instead (so much better).
title: Just spend the extra for a dot

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Chris G.
content: Flex can hear you farther than the 1st Dot.  My Kitchen Flex is constantly eavesdropping while I'm talking to the LivingRoom Dot. Flex's integration is awesome, and in some instances, better than Dot. However, her voice needs an upgrade in both quality and volume.  It's almost painful to listen to her relatively squeaky voice especially when you combine it with a Max 10 Volume sounding close to a 3 Volume Dot. The only solution is to get a constant-power BT Speaker to sync with her.  Maybe that's why they gave the flex a USB charging port. Well, for the price I paid for her, the $10 cheap speaker is still a good deal.
title: Ears like a wolf, mouth like a mouse.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Alisha
content: I bought the flex for a specific purpose. To use in my basement to disarm my alarm so we can enter/exit the basement door and for the Alexa guard abilities since I have windows in my basement.  We don't use the basement door often, so I didn't want to waste a dot for that use, plus there is no convenient place to put a dot. The flex is perfect here. I also purchased the light mostly to play with and have been impressed with it as well. The flex is not for listening to music, and if you get one for that you will be disappointed. It is a device whose main purpose is to control smart devices, integrate Alexa in lesser used spaces, or for very small rooms where a dot would be too much. I think the light or motion sensor should come with the flex so I deducted a star, but in all honesty, I don't need either one for my use. It is also funny to have Alexa say 'Get out of my basement!' when motion is detected.
title: Works well for its intended purpose.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Yams
content: Replaced an older gen 2 echo dot and was surprised at how crisp the voice is. However the sound and “bass” was significantly worse than the dot which itself is already on the lower scale in sound quality. With that said, I’m not using this for music but for an additional voice prompt in a different part of the house so I don’t have to yell into the next room...so this does the job perfectly - range of voice pickup is as good as previously from what I can tell, and the convenience of being able to put into an outlet and still leave the other outlet available is a plus. Price is right too!
title: Not meant for music but gets the job done

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: David W.
content: The mic on this device is terrible.  I was used to speaking to a normal echo dot or the full size echo, but this one is nowhere near as sensitive as those.  Nearly every time I want to use it I have to repeat myself 2-3 times, each louder than the last.  Once you can get it to respond it operates like any other Alexa device but getting it to wake up is a miserable.  Even my Echo Auto has better voice pickup than this thing does. It is also lacking volume control buttons.  It's even harder to get it to wake up when it's playing music.  I have to yell at the thing to get it to respond. I used this to replace an Echo Dot next to my bathroom sink because I didn't like having it on the counter top and I didn't like the cord running to it.  I like the idea of it plugging directly into the wall but the mic problem has to be fixed.  It pairs with my blue tooth speaker easily. Amazon has a dozen better Alexa devices than this one.  Save your money and some frustration and find something else.  I wish I did.
title: Terrible voice recognition and no volume buttons

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Tiffany
content: I have a lot of echoes and echo dots, and I often buy them for presents. I am a huge fan! However, I'm very disappointed in this flex. It was great when I got it. I plugged it in, and it booted up and immediately worked like my dots. I didn't  need to set it up with my Alexa app or anything. Great right? Well, it was until it just stopped working after one month. All my other echoes from months and months ago still fine, but this seems poorly made. The speaker produces a very tinny sound which I could live with as it was in a room I don't use too often, but conking out after only one month is unacceptable.I don't recommend the flex.
title: Was wonderful, but stopped working after one month

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Eric C. Paulsen
content: I bought these for my moms cabin up north to help control and monitor the environmentals. After I received them on the 6th I plugged each one in, connected it to my software and network, then checked/changed settings and ran it through its paces to ensure they were all up to snuff. The problem was that two of them, even though they responded to ‘alexa’, had an error that it was waiting for wakeword which never updated. Not a huge problem unless I want to change the wakeword, which knowing me as I do, I probably will. I deregistered all three and oddly all of my information remained on the device, even the changes to alarms and audio, which seems wrong. So I factory reset all three and guess what? All of my information was STILL on the device afterward! Amazon needs to address this issue right quick! Six days later now each unit is able to let me change the wakeword. I have worked in IT and work logically and methodically and I don’t understand this inexplicable change since there has been no software update. As for the personal info issue - this may be the one reason I’d send these back.
title: Bought three, two were... not quite right upon testing.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: azureglow
content: I needed an Alexa device to connect to our whole house audio.  I wanted to connect it to our Echo Show, byt Amazon does not put an audio jack on them and Bluetooth is always timing out.  I used a regular Dot I had and it worked great. I was going to buy another Dot, but now they are too fancy and expensive.  Then I stumbled upon the Echo Flex.  It does everything the Dot does except for extremely poor speaker.  The flex is very compact, very inexpensive and the audio out of its audio jack is just as good as the Dot.  I recommend the Flex if you are using alternate speakers or just want something to yell commands at for other components.  I have a Dot in the bathroom, but with the bracket I'm using, it covers both power outlets.  I'm going to replace it with a Flex and an external speaker.  It will be nice to not have a USB cord and power supply.  BTW, i stuck the Flex on the end of an extension cord and just have it lying up behind the audio equipment out of site.  It still hears me fine.
title: Just what I needed

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: rudykg
content: If you’re thinking this is a cheap Echo Dot that you don’t have to mount, you’d be wrong. This is something quite different that’s meant for another purpose. The sound is a quite a bit “tinny”. It’s meant to mainly be a receiver not a speaker. You can have an echo dot answer instead of this device if you want good sound. You can also hook up a Bluetooth or wired speaker (but that's an extra cost). So why do I have it? Guard Mode is part of my home security. I keep this in my bathroom to detect glass breaks. This is a cheaper alternative to a dot. I also pair this with my shower speaker. The USB plug is a bit handy as well. I know it’s really meant for the motion sensor or night light, but I use it as a charger. Update: After a few months, I'm happy with it. It's better than my Echo Input (no wires plus a small speaker) and if I connect a speaker to it, it's just like having a regular Echo Dot.
title: Not like an Echo Dot (updated)

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ryan Scott
content: I like the idea of the night light and motion detector, though I wish I could put them both on there. I went with the night light, but wish I had gone with the motion instead.  The sound is shallow without a lot of range. I also feel like it can't hear as well. I already had an echo dot and thought that this would do well in the kitchen since it's more out of the way. Unfortunately, it's just not that great of quality. I was hoping for better sound. Either you turn it down low and barely hear it or you turn it up and suffer the distortion. Stick with the echo dot instead, that thing is great.
title: Go with the echo dot instead

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: David S.
content: The Eco Flex enables you to conveniently add voice recognition to other rooms after you've installed your "base" Alexa with a high fidelity speaker in your home.  I recommend pairing the Flex with an Alexa Echo Dot or Echo Plus. Yes, the Flex has a speaker, but it's suited mostly for feedback from Alexa responding to your commands or questions. Music sounds tinny.  I love the Flex's USB port, which enabled me to charge an auxiliary Sony SRS-XB12 speaker, plus I used the Flex's 3.5mm jack to feed audio direct into the Sony.  But the Flex can be your one and only Alexa device if you're on a budget.
title: An affordable way to add Alexa to additional rooms

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Angeleeg
content: I had been tossing the idea around in purchasing this for my bathroom. I wanted an Alexa speaker so that I could listen to music in addition to asking Alexa about the time and weather all while getting ready for work in the morning. The reason it took me so long to purchase, was because other reviewers had stated that the sound was very low and you could hardly understand Alexa and hear music being streamed. After reading just ONE review from someone stating they had bought it for their bathroom and it was everything that they wanted it to be with sound volume and size, I decided to purchase. To my surprise, it was everything I wanted it to be. The volume emitted was perfect and I could hear the music perfectly while in the shower. I love that I can ask Alexa what time it is while i'm busy using my hands with a curling iron/ straightener. It's also the perfect size for such a small space and limited counter space.
title: Perfect for the Bathroom

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: EDISONTECH
content: OMG! Amazon! Your Alexa sale really got me to buy 2 more Alexas for my house. Now I have 3 total in my house! So far, both have been amazing! I have one in the bathroom to ask for the morning news, weather, and the time. This is called the “Flex” because of the flexibility to relocate it to anywhere there is WiFi access. The response tome is about the same as my 3rd gen Dot. This Alexa is small but I see room for improvement for this tiny device. I don’t get why it is so huge but the audio is sub-par. (I would guess the AC to DC conversion but how much space does it need?) They could of easily put inside a bigger speaker driver in the space. If they could do it for the Echo Auto, so can they do it for the flex. On the flip side, one thing I like about the Flex is that I can plug in my own speakers and usb device in with no problems (has 3.5mm headphone jack on the side and a USB A port on the bottom). I recommend getting this product when it is on sale as it is a great value.
title: Loved it so much, I got a second one!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Audrey
content: I love my echo flex. My socket in the bathroom didn’t work well with my original dot so I went ahead and gave this guy a try. Once paired with a bluetooth shower speaker that can automatically connect thereafter, the Flex is a great option for bathroom set ups. I use mine to read audiobooks to me while I shower. I will also use it to read to me while in the bath and will follow along with my kindle paper white while sipping wine. It’s the little joys in life and this guy definitely enhances those moments in the bathroom. ❤️
title: Works best when connected to shower speaker.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: zwis
content: It’s exactly what it looks like - a small, plug-in box that brings Alexa to even more places. The sound quality isn’t the best, but for the price I wasn’t expecting it to be. Besides, it has an audio port to attach any external speaker one could want. Sometimes it has difficulties hearing me when playing music at full volume, but its just minor difficulties, I’ve never had to stand there yelling at it in order for it to hear me. I’ve found this super especially useful around the house with making ‘Alexa announcements’. We have a flex in our kitchen, and another in my fathers office (which is located outside in a garage). He never has his phone on him, so whenever it’s time for dinner we no longer have to run outside to let him know, we can simply say “Alexa, announce dinner time!” and he will know! I’ve also been using a flex in my bedroom with the motion sensor attachment, and WOW does it feel otherworldly to get home from work and have my house greet me with my lights and tv coming on and a little ‘hello’. This is by FAR the cheapest option to adding motion sensors to Alexa to automate routines, all others I could find required some sore of hub (which is too expensive) or were in themselves too expensive. Great little product made by amazon, and such a fantastic call letting a third party make a motion sensor attachment for it.
title: Great little box

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Doug
content: I already had a Echo 3rd Gen, Echo 2nd Gen, and Echo Dot 2nd Gen in my house. The two Echos quickly became the "go to" device for playing background music downstairs. The Echo Dot I have in my upstairs office/cave and it's hooked up to a decent sound bar along with my TV. I also have a few indoor and outdoor lights that I control with Alexa. I bought two of these Echo Flexes using a "buy 2" discount code that was available at time of purchase.  I hooked one up to a Pioneer receiver in my basement and the other to a Pioneer receiver in my shop (that powers both indoor and outdoor speakers).  Alexa jams pretty good when you strap her to 200 watts! Seems to be working great and now I can call up music regardless of where I am on my property, and I can sync the music through multiple devices when I choose.
title: Alexa jams pretty good when you strap her to 200 watts!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Theduck71
content: This is a great device for small areas, like bathrooms, and small kitchens. The sound quality is what you would expect, for such a small device. One of the great features is that it can plug into other external speakers through a 3.5 mm jack. The best feature in my opinion, is the little devices you can plug into it. Currently, there are two, a little light and a motion sensor. Which, I am not sure why there is another one, as there is one built into it. Perhaps the external one is more sensitive. Either way, it’s a great little night light. It is also able to change colors. I have used Red, White and Blue. Not certain if it can do other colors. Also, I have noticed that it turns itself on around 730, and I noticed this morning it turned itself off. So, looks like it learns behavior as well.  Overall worth the price.
title: It a very flexible device. (Pun intended)

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Oliver
content: AS far as Echo devices go this is by far the most convenient - just plug it into the wall and you're good to go without the need for desk space. This does everything you would expect an Echo device to do, but it has one glaring flaw that was enough to knock it down two whole stars. That flaw is the audio quality. The sound out of is sounds like it's coming out of an old transistor radio. It sounds like you're listening to a bad recording of a recording of an echo over the phone. Now it's a small device so I'm not expecting audiophile sound quality, but any low end at all would be welcome. The saving grace and why this didn't get knocked down any lower is that you can hook this up either to a Bluetooth speaker or via the 3.5mm audio jack to an amp or to powered speakers. The USB port on the bottom is a nice touch even though I have yet to try one of the Flex accessories.
title: Convenient device with terrible sound

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kindle Customer
content: In our house, so long as not actually showering, these devices are working out great in our two family bathrooms (third unit in the family room). We can each brush our teeth etc and hear just fine. It's got a tiny speaker, so playing music isn't some all immersive experience, but it passes the time while brushing hair, shaving, or applying cosmetics. I'm not one to feel that every minute must be multi-tasked. However, what used to be several random boring parts of the day, now has the possibility of a few minutes of helpful productivity or just relaxation. We can knock out a couple tasks (shopping list, check the weather, log weight) or even learning (language lessons, podcasts, Audible, etc). We can listen to music, daily news, or check traffic for the morning commute. The night light add-on is also very handy in one of the bathrooms. Our third Echo Flex with add-on light, is located near a dimly lit couples of steps near an entrance. This is a very useful little device.
title: So long as you're not showering...

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: GOHARD
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. This device is so very convenient.  I love how saved space unlike the rest of the devices unless you buy an holder for it.  The sound on this device also sounds great for it to not be a giant speaker like other devices. It also hears my voice extremely well.  I am very very happy with my new device!
title: Plug it in... PLUG IT IN!!!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Solo Nur Ali
content: This little Flex is a GAME CHANGER! For everyone that says it's not for music, I completely disagree. Here's why... Autoplay Amazon Music Autoplay Podcast Autoplay News Briefing I could go on and on about it's Autoplay features, but you get the point. Put a FLEX in your bathroom, add the motion sensor, and have fun with all the Autoplay Routines you can set up. Right now I have Flex in a bathroom. Whenever my kids enter, the motion sensor triggers a Christmas playlist. I also had it setup to play the same News Briefing that my wife uses every morning. If you use this with the motion sensor, the options are really unlimited. I really think the Flex is pretty great, just as long as you're not trying to blast the music really loud. For low volume in a small room or bathroom, it sounds just fine! And I love that it works with the Alexa Announcement feature. Keep up the great work, Alexa team!
title: 🔁 Game Changer!

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Johnny Rogers
content: If you have smart devices throughout your home, this little device is very helpful to fill in those areas missed by other Alexa devices. We have a large keeping room/kitchen/breakfast area with an Echo Touchscreen and multiple dots inside or nearby. But I have to raise my voice when I'm in the kitchen area in order to turn on/off my garbage disposal, range hood, etc. By adding this little Flex near my sink, I no longer have to shout to be heard over those noisy kitchen appliances. The mic is so good, the Flex sometimes hears things when dots and my screen devices don't. Of course, that's good and bad, because the speakers are much better on all of my other devices, and I'd rather they answer before the Flex does. But I love that I don't have to shout over noisy appliances now. And I'm glad there is a simple solution for my guest baths--where I need smart home connectivity.
title: Perfect for Smart Homes

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: RaLawinger
content: It functions fine. Integrates fine. Etc. Etc... but the speaker is so quiet and quality is subpar. I asked for this for Christmas to replace my echo dot (w/additional speakers) because it was 'bulky' on my countertop in the kitchen; however, I have very frequent connection issues with this device. In the past 7 days, it has disconnected 3 times and it disconnects about 1x a week at a minimum. Easy enough fix. I unplug and replug back in, which solves the issue, but this shouldn't be happening so frequently in the first place. I may be switching back to my dot, but I do really like the nightlight accessory I also received as a gift. I enjoy going to the kitchen at night without having to switch all lights on (open concept house). Anyway, would I ask for this again as a gift or buy myself? No. I would not. Save yourself the disappointment and stick with your Echo Dot.
title: It's fine... Not as good as my regular Dot though

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ron Kramer
content: I didn't read the product desctription well as it was on sale and I nabbed two quickly.  SETUP was a breeze (it would not accept wake word until I deleted the Alexa app and re-downloaded a new version to my phone. Then pretty automatic. Works well,  SPEAKER is POOR - instead of a night light add on - why not offer a  SPEAKER USB PORT ADD ON! I put one of these on my front and back porches. (we sit out there).  And hoped the music would sound decent.  If I have to spend a lot on a speaker, I should have gotten a full echo. (that has great speaker, I use one in my bedroom) and a Alexa show with screen in the kitchen.  BOth excellent speakers for background music.  The flex speaker is poor.  Upon looking - I see in the desciption is mentions this.  If they know this why not offer a optional USB PORT ADD ON UNDER THE DEVICE with a good speaker?
title: NEEDS A SPEAKER

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Stranded Candid
content: It's great to enable a bunch of skills but then hard to remember all you've enabled. Best features are 'find my phone', the temp and forecast, can call your contacts which might help someone if they fall as long as they can remember to say Alexas name. Also nice is to ask for the latest news update and setting alarms and reminders. BIGGEST problem is that for me, by far, is voice recognition. I have a Southern accent but come on! I also wish you could increase the volume more, even if you can't increase the sound quality. I guess it was worth buying one at 50% off but about a week after I bought an Echo Flex, I bought an Echo Dot and the difference in volume and sound quality is about to be 10-fold. If you can buy an Echo Dot at 50% off it would be a DEFINITELY be worth paying the extra fee $8!!
title: Wait for an update Echo Dot at half price instead

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Ji-Ho Song
content: I bought mine on sale and of course it is cheap and you get what you pay for. I paid 10 dollars for it and the quality of the speaker is worthy of 10 dollars. HOWEVER! You can always use the bluetooth and connect to a better tiny bass boosted speaker like I did for music and have no problems besides how far your speaker can go in distance bluetooth wise. Voice recognition is good, if your surroundings are rather loud, as usual, it will be harder for Alexa to hear you. But mine can hear me around the corner in the kitchen with the TV on a good listening volume.  I have three, two for the bathrooms and one for in the garage. A very nice and cheap alternative. Just don't expect a quality speaker when this device goes on sale for 10 dollars from time to time. Waiting on a sale is best.
title: It's Cheap and It Works

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Dale R.
content: This is a nice device that adds an extension of Alexa to another home location for voice-activated services. However, the speaker is absolutely terrible. Volume controls don't appear to have a good decibel range. I'm mainly using it as a night light in my bathroom with an add-on device--which I love. This device isn't meant for music playback either, since the speaker is weak. Overall this is a very nice device to get if you need to extend Alexa to another part of your home for homes services/functions.
title: Good, Not Great.

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Dogowner
content: I gave this as a holiday gift last December 2019 and my godmother still loves it to the current day. She has it in her bedroom and connected to her Alexa 5 and she says she can talk to her BFf Alexa without any problems and or her Ring. So clearly it’s a winner and a great gift to friends and family
title: Great gift to family and friends

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Sleuth
content: Don't get me wrong.  I really like my Echo Flex.  I'm giving it one star so Amazon will pay attention to this problem. I used Alexa on my Kindle Fire HD 8 to set up my new Echo Flex and everything was fine until I tried to pair the Flex with any of my Bluetooth speakers.  According to my Fire, the Flex couldn't find any Bluetooth devices. I called Amazon and they were good enough to send me a replacement.  Unfortunately it had the same problem.  I then tried to pair each of my four Echo Dots with any of my Bluetooth speakers using Alexa on my Fire and, yet again, none of the Dots could find any Bluetooth devices. Finally, I tried using Alexa on my Android phone to do the pairing and, lo and behold, it worked perfectly.  If Amazon puts this fix in their knowledge database they will be able to address the problem I had without shipping out unnecessary replacements.
title: Won't Pair With A Bluetooth Speaker If You Use A Kindle Fire HD 8 For Setup

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Otter-Play
content: Once you get this device up and running, it generally works well, the problem is in its installation and setup.  I have two of these now and each one shows the same difficulties in setup.  The first one set up great, but then lost connection, over and over, even though well within wifi range.  Each time the device looses connection we have to re-initialize it, reconnect and it is a pain, adding the device again, with the old device still listed but with "offline".  Finally got it to connect and it has been working great since then.  The second device shows' the same problem in connection and I still don't have it working right.  So while the concept is good and once it is working all is fine, there obviously are bugs in the device that need to be worked out.
title: Good device that needs some work

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: manuamazon
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. I like it because I don't have to buy accessories to put it in an outlet or cables like echo dot, that's why I have it high on my bed, the connection between echo devices is excellent. If you want to charge your cell phone, it has a usb port. Negative part: the voice recognition does not place five stars since from what I see two microphone inputs not as an eco dot, obviously it does not recognize me more than 2 meters unless you want to speak louder. It also didn't place five stars on the sound because it obviously doesn't have very good speakers but it does the necessary work. But if you are thinking of having speakers with good voice recognition, buy echo dot, but I am glad because I can buy another one and put a speaker with auxiliary cable and that's it.
title: Its a good product works on engl/spanish very well

product: Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa
author: Kenneth Youngstrom
content: When it first came out the Flex would not play a number of Tune-In streams including Venice Classic Radio to which we listen frequently so I have waited to review it.  The problem has now been fixed, so a review is in order.  If you can get it cheap enough as compared with a Dot, this is an excellent device to use as an internet radio.  Although the Flex speaker is a joke for anything but echo responses (Amazon clearly stresses this), just add any good set of powered speakers like a moderately good computer speaker set with sub woofer and you have a pretty neat and compact internet radio, assuming that you are a Prime subscriber with access to Amazon Music. Its compact form makes it very convenient as well.  A nice addition to the Echo lineup.
